		<title>Bendigo Wealth launched - A new era in wealth management at Bendigo and Adelaide Bank</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/bendigo-wealth-launched-a-new-era-in-wealth-management-at-bendigo-and-adelaide-bank/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 11 Apr 2011 02:57:16 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="source" nicename="bendigo-and-adelaide-bank"><![CDATA[Bendigo and Adelaide Bank]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[financial advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-advisers"><![CDATA[financial advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="self-managed-superannuation-funds"><![CDATA[self-managed superannuation funds]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[wealth management]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="wealth-management"><![CDATA[wealth management]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?p=7525</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div id="_mcePaste">Bendigo and Adelaide Bank has announced the launch of Bendigo Wealth, a new wealth management division that will leverage off the bank’s high brand recognition and leading customer satisfaction ranking.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Managing Director, Mike Hirst said, “As Bendigo and Adelaide Bank has grown, so too has our ability to understand how we can better meet the needs and expectations of our distribution partners.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">“Our distribution partners told us that they would appreciate the greater convenience of new bundling options and a similar look and feel across our product range. These conversations have been very valuable in setting the direction of our wealth business and we will now bring these findings to life.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">“The realignment and expansion of our wealth management operations will see us pursue opportunities that will position the group to manage a greater share of the growing Australian managed investment pool, along with life, risk and general insurance that our distribution partners may have overlooked when dealing with one part of our wealth offering”, Mr Hirst concluded.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Bendigo Wealth Executive, John Billington said: “In keeping with our aim to be Australia’s leading customer connected banking group, we undertook a survey of our retail banking customers, financial advisers and also included people who didn’t currently have a relationship with us.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">“Overwhelmingly, they thought Bendigo Wealth as a name was appealing and best encapsulated the full suite of products and services we’re now delivering.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">“Bendigo Wealth as a brand will make it easier for our highly valued distribution partners to explain the product range to clients - and for clients to more easily make the connection to a financial services brand that they both recognise and trust.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">“What we needed was a simple way for our distribution partners to be able to connect to the full suite of financial services and products we now have on offer after the various mergers, acquisitions and partnering arrangements the bank has undertaken in recent years.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">“We also want to make it easier for financial advisers to not only be able to see the full range of investment solutions we offer, but to make it easier for them when they are having conversations with their clients about our products. The dots are easier to join for all parties and investing with the Bendigo and Adelaide Bank group is now an easier story for advisers to tell.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">“This is an exciting new era in the evolution of the Bendigo and Adelaide Bank group and I look forward to seeing Bendigo Wealth play an increasingly important role in helping our distribution partners meet the needs of their clients.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">“The Bendigo ‘experience’ is deeply embedded in the DNA of Bendigo Wealth. We are highly recognised and awarded for epitomising service, reliability and trust as a bank and this tradition and heritage will continue to grow with the launch of Bendigo Wealth”, Mr Billington concluded.<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:6:{s:5:"width";s:3:"988";s:6:"height";s:3:"734";s:14:"hwstring_small";s:23:"height='96' width='128'";s:4:"file";s:25:"2011/04/Job-slowdown1.png";s:5:"sizes";a:2:{s:9:"thumbnail";a:3:{s:4:"file";s:25:"Job-slowdown1-150x150.png";s:5:"width";s:3:"150";s:6:"height";s:3:"150";}s:6:"medium";a:3:{s:4:"file";s:25:"Job-slowdown1-300x222.png";s:5:"width";s:3:"300";s:6:"height";s:3:"222";}}s:10:"image_meta";a:10:{s:8:"aperture";s:1:"0";s:6:"credit";s:0:"";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:0:"";s:17:"created_timestamp";s:1:"0";s:9:"copyright";s:0:"";s:12:"focal_length";s:1:"0";s:3:"iso";s:1:"0";s:13:"shutter_speed";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:0:"";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

		<title>Cautious consumers</title>

		<item>
		<title>SMSF strategies: balancing longevity and investment risk </title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/smsf-strategies-balancing-longevity-and-investment-risk/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 11 Apr 2011 23:07:54 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[assets]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="assets"><![CDATA[assets]]></category>

		<category domain="source" nicename="charter-hall-direct-property-and-strategy-steps"><![CDATA[Charter Hall Direct Property and Strategy Steps]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[commodities]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="commodities"><![CDATA[commodities]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[consumers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="consumers"><![CDATA[consumers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[financial advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-advisers"><![CDATA[financial advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Financial planners]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-planners"><![CDATA[Financial planners]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Financial planning]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-planning-2"><![CDATA[Financial planning]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[From the Source]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="from-the-source"><![CDATA[From the Source]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Fund Management]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="fund-management"><![CDATA[Fund Management]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="investment-strategy"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[retirement]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="retirement"><![CDATA[retirement]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[self-managed superannuation funds]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="self-managed-superannuation-funds"><![CDATA[self-managed superannuation funds]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?p=7549</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div id="_mcePaste">Self managed super funds (SMSFs) mindful of both longevity and investment risk should consider using direct property in their portfolio, according to a new report from Charter Hall Direct Property and Strategy Steps, provider of independent technical and investment services.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div>With almost half of female and 34% of male baby boomers expected to live past 90, those in or nearing retirement need to address to longevity risk.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">"SMSFs are increasingly thinking about the need to grow wealth, but are still hesitant to move away from defensive assets. This is why we decided to undertake this report with Strategy Steps," said Richard Stacker, CEO of Charter Hall Direct Property.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">The report shows investors have a tendency to sell down growth assets at the bottom of the cycle due to concerns about their retirement savings, but this actually locks in their capital losses and portfolio of future growth assets.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">"They are then stuck with lower levels of growth assets in their portfolio which may provide insufficient retirement funds, and as a result actually increase longevity risk," said Mr Stacker.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Strategies to manage longevity risk include ensuring there is an appropriate exposure to growth assets, reducing the drawdown on capital in times of market downturns, accelerating returns via conservative gearing and investing in assets which provide tax deferred benefits.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Direct property provides high, tax effective income and capital growth when compared to assets like cash and fixed interest. It also has a low volatility and a low correlation to shares. Including direct property in a balanced portfolio can improve investors total returns with lower volatility compared to a portfolio that does not include direct property.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">For SMSF members nearing retirement, a proportion of the tax paid on property income is also deferred and is paid when the asset is sold, at which point the tax liability could be zero.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Charter Hall has recently opened to two direct property funds which are suitable for SMSFs. The Charter Hall Direct Industrial Fund (DIF), launched in July 2010, has raised $46 million of equity since launch. The Charter Hall Direct Retail Fund (DRF) was launched in February 2011 targeting high net worth and SMSF investors. DRF was established with an initial portfolio of six properties valued at $177 million, comprising a diverse portfolio with locations in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Tenants include Woolworths Supermarkets, Coles Supermarkets, Big W, Bunnings, JB Hi-Fi, The Good Guys and Spotlight. The Fund has been awarded Lonsec's second highest rating1, 'Recommended Upper End'.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">"There are a number of ways to make sure a retiree is structuring their portfolio in order to reduce, rather than increase longevity risk. Investors should be realising the market cycle is ripe, particularly in property to be reconsidering their allocation to overly defensive asset classes," Mr Stacker said.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<h3>Strategies for pension portfolios<span style="color: #ffffff; font-weight: normal;">X</span></h3>
<div id="_mcePaste">The report also provides some strategies for structuring a pension portfolio to manage longevity risk.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Strategy 1: Aim to protect against market volatility in the early years by ensuring growth assets do not need to be sold to make pension payments.</div>
<div id="_mcePaste">
<ul>
	<li>Separate the portfolio into cash and growth and draw income from only from the income portfolio</li>
	<li>Put secure investments like cash and around 2-3 years worth of income in the income portfolio</li>
	<li>Allocate the remainder of the portfolio to growth-based diversified portfolios</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div id="_mcePaste"><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div>This strategy means the income section is not affected by market volatility and leaves growth assets intact, allowing for more aggressive investment.</div>
<div id="_mcePaste"><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>Strategy 2: Balanced/growth diversified portfolio</div>
<div>
<ul>
	<li>Allocate portfolio assets according to the client/s risk profile</li>
	<li>Draw income proportionally from all assets to maintain asset allocation</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div id="_mcePaste"><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div>This strategy allows the balance/growth asset allocation to be matched to the client's risk profile and can produce overall higher performance in a good market.</div>
<span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman'; line-height: normal; font-size: small;"><strong>
</strong></span>
<div class="disclaimer">

<strong>Important information </strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman'; line-height: normal; font-size: small;"><strong> </strong></span>

<strong> </strong>

<strong> </strong><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman'; line-height: normal; font-size: small;">1. The Lonsec Limited ("Lonsec") ABN 56 061 751 102 rating (assigned December 2010) presented in this document is limited to "General Advice" and based solely on consideration of the investment merits of the financial product(s). It is not a recommendation to purchase, sell or hold the relevant product(s), and you should seek independent financial advice before investing in this product(s). The rating is subject to change without notice and Lonsec assumes no obligation to update this document following publication. Lonsec receives a fee from the fund manager for rating the product(s) using comprehensive and objective criteria.</span><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman'; line-height: normal; font-size: small;"> </span><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman'; line-height: normal; font-size: small;">Units in the Charter Hall Direct Retail Fund ("DRF") and Charter Hall Direct Industrial Fund ("DIF") are made available by Charter Hall Direct Property Management Limited (ACN 56 073 623 784, AFSL 226849) ("CHDPML") under a Product Disclosure Statement ("PDS"). Potential investors should consider the PDS before making any decisions regarding the offer. Copies of the PDS can be obtained from CHDPML by calling 1300 652 790 (local call cost). This announcement has been prepared for information purposes only. It is not intended to be, and does not constitute a PDS, prospectus, short form prospectus or profile statement as those terms are defined in the Corporations Act. It does not constitute an offer for the issue, sale or purchase of any securities, or any recommendation in relation to investing in any asset. This document has been prepared without taking account of any particular investor's objectives, financial situation or needs. For this reason, it is important that you consider the PDS for the offer and seek appropriate professional advice before making any investment decision. CHDPML does not receive fees in respect of the general financial product advice it may provide, however it will receive fees for operating DRF or DIF which, in accordance with the Fund's Constitution, are calculated by reference to the value of the assets of and performance of DRF or DIF. Entities within the Charter Hall Group may receive fees for managing the assets of, and providing resources to DRF. For more detail on fees, see the PDS. To contact us call 1300 652 790 (local call cost). © Charter Hall Group, 2010</span>

</div>]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Disturbing slowdown</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/jobs-up-but-slowdown-clear-over-time/disturbing-slowdown-4/</link>

		<item>
		<title>ASIC proposes major improvements in quality of prospectuses</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/asic-proposes-major-improvements-in-quality-of-prospectuses/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 12 Apr 2011 02:39:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="source" nicename="asic-australian-securities-investments-commission"><![CDATA[ASIC - Australian Securities &amp; Investments Commission]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[ASIC regulation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="asic-regulation"><![CDATA[ASIC regulation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[consumers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="consumers"><![CDATA[consumers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[financial advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-advisers"><![CDATA[financial advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Financial planners]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-planners"><![CDATA[Financial planners]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Financial planning]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-planning-2"><![CDATA[Financial planning]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[financial services]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-services"><![CDATA[financial services]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Fund Management]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="fund-management"><![CDATA[Fund Management]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Industry Bodies]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="industry-bodies"><![CDATA[Industry Bodies]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="investment-strategy"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[reform]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="reform"><![CDATA[reform]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[self-managed superannuation funds]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="self-managed-superannuation-funds"><![CDATA[self-managed superannuation funds]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?p=7489</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div id="_mcePaste">ASIC is proposing an overhaul of prospectuses that would make them much easier for retail investors to use and would improve the quality of information on the proposed business model and the associated risks.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div>ASIC Commissioner Belinda Gibson said the proposals – which are the subject of consultation with industry – were aimed at ensuring the focus of prospectuses is high-quality information that investors can understand, and which gives investors a full picture of the offer.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div>"Under ASIC's proposals, prospectuses will focus on information that is relevant to the investment decision, will be easier to follow, will give investors a better picture of what they are being offered, how the company will make money and generate returns for investors, the associated risks, who will manage the company, and how they will run it", Belinda Gibson said.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div>"First and foremost, a prospectus is a disclosure document aimed at informing investors. Sales and marketing statements – and the extensive use of promotional photography - are secondary," Belinda Gibson said. "The consultation paper raises for discussion the proper balance that we should achieve".</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div>ASIC's proposals are contained in two documents that have been released today - Consultation Paper 155 [CP 155] Prospectus disclosure: Improving disclosure for retail investors, and an accompanying draft regulatory guide.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div>Consultation with industry on the proposals in the paper will continue until 7 June 2011, after which ASIC will issue a new regulatory guide – taking into account the results of the consultation. ASIC has already undertaken extensive consultation in arriving at the proposals that it is making public, and it has drawn on consumer research.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div>The consultation paper and draft regulatory guide cover prospectuses issued under section 710 of the Corporations Act 2001. Generally, these are prospectuses for initial public offerings and for companies that propose to list. The guidance is also relevant to other types of prospectuses as well as some other documents. The table below summarises the shortcomings that ASIC has identified in prospectuses, and the proposed response:</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div>click to view <a href="http://www.asic.gov.au/asic/pdflib.nsf/LookupByFileName/CP155-Published-12-April-2011.pdf/$file/CP155-Published-12-April-2011.pdf">CP 155</a></div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;"><a rel="attachment wp-att-7495" href="http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/asic-proposes-major-improvements-in-quality-of-prospectuses/asic-review-on-prospectuses-2/"><img class="alignleft size-large wp-image-7495" title="ASIC review on prospectuses" src="http://www.adviservoice.com/dev/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/ASIC-review-on-prospectuses1-978x1024.png" alt="" width="493" height="516" /></a>
</span></div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>]]></content:encoded>

							</item>
		<item>
		<title>FPA calls on Minister Shorten to recognise financial planning profession under law</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/fpa-calls-on-minister-shorten-to-recognise-financial-planning-profession-under-law/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 12 Apr 2011 21:49:45 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[consumers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="consumers"><![CDATA[consumers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[financial advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-advisers"><![CDATA[financial advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[financial planner]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-planner"><![CDATA[financial planner]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[financial planning professionals]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-planning-professionals"><![CDATA[financial planning professionals]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[financial products]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-products"><![CDATA[financial products]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[financial services]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-services"><![CDATA[financial services]]></category>

		<category domain="source" nicename="fpa-financial-planning-association"><![CDATA[FPA - Financial Planning Association]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Industry Bodies]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="industry-bodies"><![CDATA[Industry Bodies]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[investment]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="investment"><![CDATA[investment]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[reform]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="reform"><![CDATA[reform]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[regulation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="regulation"><![CDATA[regulation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[self-managed superannuation funds]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="self-managed-superannuation-funds"><![CDATA[self-managed superannuation funds]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?p=7530</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Minimum standards and legislative support benefits for all Australians</h3>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">The Financial Planning Association (FPA) today called upon Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Financial Services and Superannuation Bill Shorten to consider a proposal that would restrict the use of the term ‘Financial Planner’ under law.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>"The title of Financial Planner should be restricted under law for use by members of an approved professional association, governed by the highest ethical, educational and professional standards," FPA chairman Matthew Rowe, told an FPA luncheon attended by Minister Shorten today.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>"The FPA believes this to be a fundamental public confidence issue. Consumers deserve the right to differentiate between a qualified, professional financial planner and anyone who happens to hang out a shingle calling themselves a financial planner."</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">The FPA received overwhelming support to become a professional association with over 94 per cent of members voting in favour of a new three year strategic plan at an EGM last week.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">"The FPA now has a clear and unambiguous mandate to be a professional association for practitioner members only and we have a world leading professional framework for Financial Planners," Mr Rowe said.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">"Similar professions that deal with matters of public interest, such as tax agents and stockbrokers, have the force of legislation behind them and we believe financial planning should be no different."</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Currently, under the Corporations Act 2001, there is no constraint on individuals calling themselves financial planners irrespective of their training, competence, and even licensing. The FPA believes this puts consumers’ at risk of receiving poor advice from incompetent providers and creates consumer confusion as to the difference between financial planners, professional advisers, and others.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">"There is a high level of confusion in the market - within industry, media, Government and consumers - about the definitions and roles of financial planners, advisers, and those that sell financial products," FPA CEO Mark Rantall said.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">"Some incorrectly use the term financial planner, seemingly unaware of the specific competency, training, licence, professional standing and services provided."</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">The FPA said the purpose of the recommendation was:</div>
<div id="_mcePaste">
<ul>
	<li>To restrict the ability for individual’s to call themselves a financial planner if they are only selling a product.</li>
	<li>To require financial planners to adhere to professional obligations by requiring planners to be members of an approved professional association.</li>
	<li>The term financial planner is increasingly being used by persons who provide non-traditional ancillary services in marketing and promotional material (attracts customers for realtors, stockbrokers, mortgage brokers etc).</li>
	<li>A definition of financial planner should improve consumer protection by capturing only true financial planners (i.e. excluding those not providing financial planning advice).</li>
	<li>Defining financial planning can either use a functional approach (state methods of practice), a holding out definition (those who hold themselves out to provide financial planning services), or a combination of both.</li>
</ul>
</div>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Manager outlook takes on international flavour, says Russell survey</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/manager-outlook-takes-on-international-flavour-says-russell-survey/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 12 Apr 2011 22:12:43 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Australian dollar]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="australian-dollar"><![CDATA[Australian dollar]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[business growth]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="business-growth-2"><![CDATA[business growth]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[commodities]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="commodities"><![CDATA[commodities]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Financial planning]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-planning-2"><![CDATA[Financial planning]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[From the Source]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="from-the-source"><![CDATA[From the Source]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[global economy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="global-economy"><![CDATA[global economy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[global markets]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="global-markets"><![CDATA[global markets]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[growth assets]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="growth-assets"><![CDATA[growth assets]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[international share market]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="international-share-market"><![CDATA[international share market]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[resource sector]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="resource-sector"><![CDATA[resource sector]]></category>

		<category domain="source" nicename="russell-investments"><![CDATA[Russell Investments]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?p=7535</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>- Managers positioning for “risk on” environment
- China key to Australian prosperity, but not without risks</h2>
<div id="_mcePaste">Recent global events have failed to suppress manager appetite for growth assets, according the latest Russell Investments Investment Manager Outlook (IMO) released today. In fact, for the first time in two and a half years Australian managers are favoring international shares over Aussie equities in a sign of increased confidence in a strong recovery across global markets.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>The quarterly survey of 36 investment managers collects their top-line opinions on the direction of markets, sectors to watch and wider trends that could impact Australian investors.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Since Russell’s December 2010 IMO, managers’ appetite for growth assets has continued to develop with bullishness towards equity markets flowing through to the first quarter of 2011 with net sentiment towards international equities reaching its highest point since the inception of the IMO in 2005.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Russell portfolio manager, Scott Bennett, said growth assets had returned to favour with managers which he attributed to stronger growth being experienced in the US and signs of a European recovery being well underway.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>“The strong Aussie dollar is making offshore assets appear cheap at current valuations and with all signs pointing to a recovery in developed international economies, managers are seeing increasing opportunities offshore,” said Mr Bennett.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<h3>Bulls rush in on materials and financials</h3>
<div>Net sentiment on materials continued to be strong this quarter, reaching the highest point in the history of the IMO. Mr Bennett said ongoing demand by China and India for Australian resources had managers expressing confidence in the strength of the sector despite the high Aussie dollar.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;"> </span>On the home front, financials have recovered much of the ground they lost over the last 12 months. Bullish managers on financials increased by 24.5 percentage points to 55% this survey.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>“Financials were looking very bearish in Q4 2010 and much of this was around fears of government policy intervention. This issue appears to have fallen by the wayside for managers this time around and the increased bullishness is a sign that people are reassured on the sector,” Mr Bennett said.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<h3>Managers keep a watchful eye on the big picture</h3>
<div>While the geopolitical events and natural catastrophes which occurred both at home and overseas in the first quarter of 2011 don’t appear to have dented managers’ confidence in international or local markets, managers are mindful of global events and the impact for Australian investors.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>Topping managers’ list of events to watch is the sustainability of China’s growth. With Australia and China inextricably linked through the demand for local resources, managers identified the risk of a China slow down as a significant watch point for Australian investors in 2011.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>“Given Australia’s reliance on resources to fuel growth, managers will be watching to see how the Chinese economy goes and whether they can maintain the double digit growth we’ve witnessed. That being said, we continue to see strong support for China and we’re expecting fairly strong growth out of that area,” Mr Bennett said.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>On the potential impact of Australian-centric issues such as government intervention in the banking sector, inflation, a skills shortage and increased union activism, managers were much more benign.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>“Managers’ bullish sentiment on the Australian market indicates a level of confidence, but local regulatory issues remain. However this concern for Australia-specific events was outweighed by the magnitude of global market shocks, which received a noticeably higher rating than local issues,” Mr Bennett concluded.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div><em>Russell Investments Investment Manager Outlook (IMO) </em><a href="https://mail.inqbase.com/exchweb/bin/redir.asp?URL=http://www.russell.com/AU/_pdfs/market-reports/imo/Russell-Investment-Manager-Outlook.pdf">Click to view</a></div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>New appointment for Lonsec’s Equity Research team</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/new-appointment-for-lonsec%e2%80%99s-equity-research-team/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 13 Apr 2011 00:29:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[debt]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="debt"><![CDATA[debt]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Emerging Markets]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="emerging-markets"><![CDATA[Emerging Markets]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[equity research]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?p=7560</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[As a result of growth in demand for specialised equity research, Lonsec has added another resource to its Equity Research team.
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>Nicholas Yaxley joined Lonsec in March 2011 to focus on researching listed fixed interest and hybrid securities.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>Nicholas previously held the position of Investment Analyst at Black Swan Capital Partners. In this role he was responsible for the development and execution of bespoke mandates, predominantly for international high net worth or sophisticated investors.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>Marcus Tuck, Head of Equity Research and Stockbroking for Lonsec commented, “Nicholas‟s experience in listed debt, equity and hybrid markets will be a welcome addition to our listed research team and should result in valuable investment ideas for our clients.”</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>Prior to Black Swan Capital Partners, his previous experience includes work as an international Credit Analyst at JP Morgan Asset Management and as a Portfolio Manager at Sumitomo Trust and Banking Co. Ltd.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>Following this appointment, Lonsec‟s Equity Research team has grown to six, supported by more than 30 other research professionals. Nicholas previously held the position of Investment Analyst at Black Swan Capital Partners. In this role he</div>
<div id="_mcePaste">was responsible for the development and execution of bespoke mandates, predominantly for international high net worth or sophisticated investors.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Marcus Tuck, Head of Equity Research and Stockbroking for Lonsec commented, “Nicholas‟s experience in listed debt, equity and hybrid markets will be a welcome addition to our listed research team and should result in valuable investment ideas for our clients.”</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>Prior to Black Swan Capital Partners, his previous experience includes work as an international Credit Analyst at JP Morgan Asset Management and as a Portfolio Manager at Sumitomo Trust and Banking Co.Ltd.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>Following this appointment, Lonsec‟s Equity Research team has grown to six, supported by more than 30 other research professionals.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>

<span style="color: #ffffff;"> </span>
<div>
<div class="disclaimer">IMPORTANT NOTICE: The following relate to this document published by Lonsec Limited ABN 56 061 751 102 ("Lonsec") and should be read before making any investment decision about the product(s). Disclosure at the date of publication: Lonsec receive a fee from the fund manager for rating the product(s) using comprehensive and objective criteria. Lonsec‟s fee is not linked to the rating outcome. Lonsec does not hold the product(s) referred to in this document. Lonsec‟s representatives and/or their associates may hold the product(s) referred to in this document, but detail of these holdings are not known to the Analyst(s). Warnings: Past performance is not a reliable indicator of future performance. Any express or implied rating or advice presented in this document is limited to “General Advice” and based solely on consideration of the investment merits of the financial product(s) alone, without taking into account the investment objectives, financial situation and particular needs („financial circumstances‟) of any particular person. Before making an investment decision based on the rating or advice, the reader must consider whether it is personally appropriate in light of his or her financial circumstances or should seek further advice on its appropriateness.  If our General Advice relates to the acquisition or possible acquisition of particular financial product(s), the reader should obtain and consider the Product Disclosure Statement for each financial product before making any decision about whether to acquire a product. Disclaimer: This document is for the exclusive use of the person to whom it is provided by Lonsec and must not be used or relied upon by any other person. No representation, warranty or undertaking is given or made in relation to the accuracy or completeness of the information presented in this document, which is drawn from public information not verified by Lonsec.  Conclusions, ratings and advice are reasonably held at the time of completion but subject to change without notice. Lonsec assumes no obligation to update this document following publication. Except for any liability which cannot be excluded, Lonsec, its directors, employees and agents disclaim all liability for any error or inaccuracy in, or omission from, this document or any loss or damage suffered by the reader or any other person as a consequence of relying upon it.</div>
</div>
</div>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>S&amp;P Assigns Three-Star Rating To MLC Global Property Securities Fund</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/sp-assigns-three-star-rating-to-mlc-global-property-securities-fund/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 13 Apr 2011 01:53:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Financial planners]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-planners"><![CDATA[Financial planners]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Financial planning]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-planning-2"><![CDATA[Financial planning]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Fund Management]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="fund-management"><![CDATA[Fund Management]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[investment]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="investment"><![CDATA[investment]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[MLC]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mlc"><![CDATA[MLC]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[property investment]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="property-investment"><![CDATA[property investment]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[property securities]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="property-securities"><![CDATA[property securities]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[self-managed superannuation funds]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="self-managed-superannuation-funds"><![CDATA[self-managed superannuation funds]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Standard &amp; Poor Ratings]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="standard-poor-ratings"><![CDATA[Standard &amp; Poor Ratings]]></category>

		<category domain="source" nicename="standard-poors"><![CDATA[Standard &amp; Poor's]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Trends]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="trends"><![CDATA[Trends]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?p=7448</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Standard &amp; Poor's Fund Services today removed from 'On Hold' and assigned its three-star rating to the MLC Global Property Securities Trust. We placed the fund 'On Hold' last year when portfolio manager Paul Duncan resigned from MLC Investment Management Ltd. The three-star rating represents a downgrade from the fund's previous four-star rating.

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>

We consider that Mr. Duncan's departure, together with Jason Hazell's departure earlier in 2010 has resulted in a loss of multi-management experience and expertise, as well as knowledge of the fund and the underlying managers. The effect of these departures has led to our reduced rating conviction.

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>

"We hold new portfolio manager, Stuart Keighran in high regard, although his multimanager role is somewhat of a departure from his previous role as a property securities fund portfolio manager," said S&amp;P Fund Services analyst Peter Ward.

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>

"We expect conviction to build as Mr. Keighran settles into his new role and builds his fund manager knowledge and relationships with assistance from his MLC team members. His strong investment experience will stand him in good stead, together with the framework provided by MLC's multi-manager research, philosophy, processes, and portfolio implementation capability," said Mr. Ward.

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>

The funds affected by this announcement are:

(headline funds in <strong>bold</strong>)
<p style="text-align: center;"><a rel="attachment wp-att-7468" href="http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/sp-assigns-three-star-rating-to-mlc-global-property-securities-fund/revised-rating-s-p-4/"><img class="size-full wp-image-7468 aligncenter" title="Revised Rating S &amp; P" src="http://www.adviservoice.com/dev/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/Revised-Rating-S-P3.png" alt="" width="500" height="150" /></a></p>
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
<p style="text-align: center;"><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></p>
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>AFA: Sarah Riegelhuth takes on role as GenXt Chair</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/afa-sarah-riegelhuth-takes-on-role-as-genxt-chair/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 13 Apr 2011 22:55:26 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[adviser education]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="adviser-education"><![CDATA[adviser education]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[AFA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="afa"><![CDATA[AFA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[appointments]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="appointments"><![CDATA[appointments]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[financial advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-advisers"><![CDATA[financial advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-planners"><![CDATA[Financial planners]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[financial services]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-services"><![CDATA[financial services]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Fund Management]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="fund-management"><![CDATA[Fund Management]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Industry Bodies]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="industry-bodies"><![CDATA[Industry Bodies]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[training advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="training-advisers"><![CDATA[training advisers]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?p=7538</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div id="_mcePaste">The Association of Financial Advisers (AFA) has announced the 2011/2012 GenXt Committee, appointing financial adviser Sarah Riegelhuth from Wealth Enhancers as Chair.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Richard Klipin, the CEO of the AFA said, “Sarah has been one of the shining lights and proud supporters of the AFA for the past four years and has distinguished herself as a finalist in the AFA’s Rising Star of the Year Awards in both 2008 and 2009. Her knowledge and passion for the advice industry make her a great choice for the position of Chair of our GenXt Program.”</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">GenXt is designed to ‘bridge the gap’ between the current and next generation of advisers, by formulating a program of events and forums to facilitate the transfer of knowledge, experience, skills and networks between the generations.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Ms Riegelhuth said she is delighted to have been selected to take on the challenge of GenXt Chair at one of the most important stages in the history of the advice industry. “It’s no secret that, with FOFA reforms about to move from theory into practice, we have some challenging times ahead,” she said. “I look forward to helping our younger advisers navigate those changes.”</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">The GenXt Roadshow, which toured the country and wrapped up late last month attracted a record number of over 1300 attendees.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>“That’s a fantastic endorsement of what we do for our younger advisers and the quality of the GenXt program,” Ms Riegelhuth said.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>“It also demonstrates the AFA’s steadfast belief in the calibre of our newest recruits.”</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">The 2011/2012 GenXt Committee includes:
<span style="color: #ffffff;">xx</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">National Team</div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Sarah Riegelhuth (Chair)</div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Michael Nowak</div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Chris Browne</div>
<div id="_mcePaste">David Pettit</div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Chris Jones (SOS)
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>NSW</div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Jo Brassett</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">VIC</div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Steve Crawford</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">QLD</div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Fraser Jack</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>TAS</div>
<div>Rob Schiliro</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>WA</div>
<div>David Pettit</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>SA</div>
<div>Dave Slovinecx</div>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>S&amp;P Fund Services Rates North Protected Retirement Guarantee As &#039;Strong&#039;</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/sp-fund-services-rates-north-protected-retirement-guarantee-as-strong/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 14 Apr 2011 00:03:13 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Fund Management]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="fund-management"><![CDATA[Fund Management]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[fund management fees]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="fund-management-fees"><![CDATA[fund management fees]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[income sequencing]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="income-sequencing"><![CDATA[income sequencing]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[inflation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="inflation"><![CDATA[inflation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[investment]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="investment"><![CDATA[investment]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[investment income]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="investment-income"><![CDATA[investment income]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="investment-strategy"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[retirement]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="retirement"><![CDATA[retirement]]></category>

		<category domain="source" nicename="standard-poors"><![CDATA[Standard &amp; Poor's]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Trends]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="trends"><![CDATA[Trends]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?p=7633</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[S&amp;P Fund Services has assigned its 'Strong' rating to the North Protected Retirement Guarantee (PRG). The rating reflects our view that the product is the superior guaranteed minimum withdrawal benefit for life (GMWB for Life) product in the market.

"In our view, PRG is superior to competing GMWB for Life products in the domestic market. It provides greater flexibility, choice of underlying funds, lower underlying fund management fees, and higher risk-return strategies. Furthermore, based on our Monte Carlo analysis, PRG generates better income and commutation value (CV) outcomes due to lower effective fees," said S&amp;P Fund Services analyst, Rodney Lay.

"PRG is effective in providing retirees with nominal income certainty, partly to address income sequencing, longevity, and market risks. It is also best suited to those in good health, with a family history of longevity, and who are concerned about outliving their income as the total return on a lifetime annuity increases the longer the investor lives," said Mr. Lay.

"However, we have two major concerns regarding GMWB for Life products, including PRG. On average, GMWB for Life products do not provide a guarantee against inflation risk, with real income expected to decline over the longer term. Furthermore, the likelihood that income payments will increase is subject to significant market-timing risks, with flat, weak or volatile market performance in the earlier stages of the investment greatly reducing the likelihood of income increases," said Mr. Lay.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Commsec 17 April</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/investor-signposts-week-beginning-april-17-2011/commsec-17-april/</link>

		<item>
		<title>Investor Signposts: Week Beginning April 17 2011</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/investor-signposts-week-beginning-april-17-2011/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 14 Apr 2011 02:25:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[business growth]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="business-growth-2"><![CDATA[business growth]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[commodities]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="commodities"><![CDATA[commodities]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="consumers"><![CDATA[consumers]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?p=7587</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>Upcoming economic and financial market events</h2>
<div id="_mcePaste" style="text-align: center;"><a rel="attachment wp-att-7588" href="http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/investor-signposts-week-beginning-april-17-2011/commsec-17-april/"><img class="size-full wp-image-7588 aligncenter" title="Commsec 17 April" src="http://www.adviservoice.com/dev/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/Commsec-17-April.png" alt="" width="581" height="174" /></a></div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<h3>The big picture</h3>
<div>
<div>
<ul>
	<li>Aussie businesses have to cope with a lot. The global environment has been far from stable in recent years, what with the financial crisis, geopolitical problems in North Africa and the Middle East and rising cost pressures, such as the lift in oil prices. Then there has been the string of natural disasters and the soaring Australian dollar. But by far one of the biggest changes in the domestic business environment is the extent of conservatism by Aussie consumers.</li>
	<li>Some economists believe that nothing has really changed – that consumers are still spending, but in different ways. Clearly these economists have spent too long in their marbled office towers. The Reserve Bank has regularly highlighted the changed behaviour of consumers; our retail clients across the country are constantly noting the tough environment; and certainly listed retailers haven’t been shy in indicating the challenges they are facing.</li>
	<li>So have there been any changes of note in recent times? The Reserve Bank is certainly watching carefully for any subtle shifts, because if consumers do start spending again, then interest rate hikes will be back on the agenda.</li>
	<li>Well there hasn’t been any improvement in retail spending. Over the past six months retail trade has grown at a 1.0 per cent annual rate. And in February alone, spending went backwards in four of the states &amp; territories with only flood-induced buying in Queensland holding up the national growth rate.</li>
	<li>Then there is the latest credit and debit card data. In February, the average credit card balance was up just 1.4 per cent on a year ago. That is actually the fourth straight month that growth in credit card debt has gone backwards in real terms.</li>
	<li>Aussie consumers are still using their credit cards to make purchases, but the clear preference is to use their own money – buy goods with their debit cards – than add purchases to the credit card bill. In February, credit card transactions were up just over 7 per cent on a year ago but debit card transactions were up by almost 23 per cent – the fastest annual growth rate recorded.</li>
	<li>And the old stand-by of the past – the credit card cash advance – has almost become a relic of history. In February the number of credit card cash advances fell to the lowest levels recorded in almost 14 years.</li>
	<li>Add in the fact that personal lending has fallen to the lowest levels seen in two years and it becomes blindingly apparent that Aussie consumers won’t spend or borrow and still very much prefer to live within their means.<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
<h3>The week ahead</h3>
<ul>
	<li><span style="font-weight: normal;">Didn’t we just celebrate Christmas? It seems like it was just yesterday, but now Easter is almost here. Fortunately for investors there is just a spattering of domestic and global economic events before the Easter break with inflation in focus at home and housing dominating the US economic releases.</span></li>
	<li>In Australia CommSec releases its quarterly “State of the States” report on Monday and a few surprises have shown up in the relative performances of the state and territory economies over the last three months.</li>
	<li>On Tuesday, the Bureau of Statistics releases March data on imports – one of the timeliest readings on the economy. And on the same day the Reserve Bank publishes minutes of the last Board meeting held on April 5. Given that the statement following the meeting was almost a carbon copy of the previous month, investors and analysts alike will be scouring the Board minutes for fresh views on the state of the economy.</li>
	<li>On Wednesday the “inflation reporting” season begins with March quarter data on international trade prices – that is, export and import prices. The Commonwealth Bank Business Sales index is also released on Wednesday. And this is followed up on Thursday with readings on business inflation – the producer price indexes.</li>
	<li>The main influences on both inflation publications are a modestly stronger currency, higher coal and iron ore prices and a near 17 per cent lift in the US dollar price of crude oil. Analysts will also closely assess the data on producer prices for evidence that businesses are trimming prices in response to competition. Alternatively some sectors may have sought to lift prices in response to increased wage costs, and that bears watching. There is certainly a mix of pressures acting on prices at present.</li>
	<li>While inflation dominates the indicators in Australia, in the US it is housing that is centre-stage. On Monday the National Association of Home Builders releases the April activity index while data on housing starts and building permits is released on Tuesday with existing home sales on Wednesday. And on Thursday the Federal Housing Finance Agency releases home price data for February.</li>
	<li>Overall economists are tipping firmer readings, especially for housing starts and existing home sales. Starts may have rebounded by 6.5 per cent in March according to consensus forecasts after a slide of 22 per cent in February. Admittedly the weather has played a big role on the results and the truth on new starts lies in between. And economists expect a 2.5 per cent lift in home sales in March after the 9.6 per cent slump in February (the first drop in four months).</li>
	<li>Of the other data, economists tip a modest 0.2 per cent lift in the leading indicators series in March after a solid 0.8 per cent rise in February. And most analysts tip an easing of the influential Philadelphia Fed index for April.</li>
</ul>
<h3>Sharemarket</h3>
<div>
<ul>
	<li>The US profit reporting season has begun. And while it doesn’t get into full swing until after Easter, there are a number of household names issuing results in the coming week. On Monday Citigroup and Texas Instruments are amongst 25 companies to report. On Tuesday there are 50 companies to report and the notables include Goldman Sachs, Johnson &amp; Johnson, State Street, US Bankcorp, IBM, Intel and Yahoo!. Amongst the 103 companies reporting on Wednesday are AT &amp; T, Delta Airlines, Morgan Stanley, Wells Fargo, American Express, Apple, E*TRADE, Qualcomm and YUM! Brands. And of the 161 companies to report on Thursday, included are DuPont, Ford, General Electric, McDonalds, Nokia, Southwest Air, Advanced Micro, Amazon.com and Verizon.</li>
	<li>Overall the consensus amongst analysts is that earnings per share in the first quarter of 2011 will be up 13 per cent on a year ago with sales up 8 per cent. TheStreet.com expects EPS for S&amp;P 500 companies at $23 a share, which would be the highest, first quarter result in history.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h3>Interest rates, currencies &amp; commodities</h3>
<div>
<ul>
	<li>Why are oil prices so high? In large part it reflects the instability in North Africa and the Middle East. From late October 2010 to late February 2011, the Nymex oil price was content to sit between US$80-92 a barrel. Then came the Libyan crisis in late February and oil quickly lifted to US$98 a barrel and then to US$102 on March 2. Oil production from Libya was never the issue, rather the concern (read: speculation) was that countries like Saudi Arabia could be affected, potentially disrupting oil supplies to the world, but Europe in particular.</li>
	<li>But what happens if stability returns? Well the world is well supplied with oil according to the International Energy Agency, even with the solid expansion of China and the rest of Asia. In fact world oil supply hit a record high of 89 million barrels per day in February with US gasoline stocks at a 20-year high – all just before the Libyan crisis hit – although both have eased over the past month. So once the geopolitical jitters ease, oil prices could retreat quickly, meaning good news for motorists and retailers alike but bad news for resources stocks.</li>
	<li>Our CBA currency strategists haven’t changed their tune. They expect that the Aussie will remain firm in the short-term, perhaps lifting as high as US108 cents. But as the US Federal Reserve prepares to withdraw stimulus in the second half of 2011 and then focuses on lifting interest rates from an unsustainable level of 0.25 per cent, the US dollar should start to strengthen. So while the Aussie dollar could ease against the greenback later this year, it will be more a matter of US dollar strength, rather than Aussie dollar weakness. The Aussie is tipped to end 2011 around US92 cents.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>

</div>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:6:{s:5:"width";s:3:"357";s:6:"height";s:3:"251";s:14:"hwstring_small";s:23:"height='89' width='128'";s:4:"file";s:34:"2011/04/Investor-Emotion-graph.png";s:5:"sizes";a:2:{s:9:"thumbnail";a:3:{s:4:"file";s:34:"Investor-Emotion-graph-150x150.png";s:5:"width";s:3:"150";s:6:"height";s:3:"150";}s:6:"medium";a:3:{s:4:"file";s:34:"Investor-Emotion-graph-300x210.png";s:5:"width";s:3:"300";s:6:"height";s:3:"210";}}s:10:"image_meta";a:10:{s:8:"aperture";s:1:"0";s:6:"credit";s:0:"";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:0:"";s:17:"created_timestamp";s:1:"0";s:9:"copyright";s:0:"";s:12:"focal_length";s:1:"0";s:3:"iso";s:1:"0";s:13:"shutter_speed";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:0:"";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

				<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key>slide_redirect_url</wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[http://www.adviservoice.com/?attachment_id=7618]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							</item>
		<item>
		<title>AFA: calls again to restrict use of the term &quot;financial advisor&quot; under legislation</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/afa-calls-again-to-restrict-use-of-the-term-financial-advisor-under-legislation/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 14 Apr 2011 22:32:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[AFA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="afa"><![CDATA[AFA]]></category>

		<category domain="source" nicename="afa-association-of-financial-advisers"><![CDATA[AFA - Association of Financial Advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[consumers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="consumers"><![CDATA[consumers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[financial advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-advisers"><![CDATA[financial advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Financial planners]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-planners"><![CDATA[Financial planners]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[financial services]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-services"><![CDATA[financial services]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[FoFA reforms]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="fofa-reforms"><![CDATA[FoFA reforms]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Industry Bodies]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="industry-bodies"><![CDATA[Industry Bodies]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[investment]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="investment"><![CDATA[investment]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[legislation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="legislation"><![CDATA[legislation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[reform]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="reform"><![CDATA[reform]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[regulation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="regulation"><![CDATA[regulation]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?p=7636</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<table border="0">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>
<h3>For better consumer protection, AFA again calls to enshrine the term "Financial adviser"</h3>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>In its 2009 submission to the Ripoll Inquiry, the Association of Financial Advisers (AFA) called for the term "Financial Adviser" which encompasses all those who work under the Australian Financial Services Licence (AFSL) regime to be enshrined in legislation.

<span style="color: #ffffff;">
</span>

"Those who work under an AFSL are obliged by law to act in the best interests of their clients," said AFA CEO Richard Klipin. "In the interests of properly protecting consumers, it is this distinction that they need to understand. It therefore makes sense to enshrine the term in legislation so that only those who work inside the AFSL tent have the right to call themselves a financial adviser/planner and belong to a professional association such as the AFA. Those who sit outside the AFSL tent should not be permitted to use the term financial adviser/planner."

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>

The AFA is Australia’s longest serving financial adviser association and this year celebrates its 65th Anniversary.

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>

"The AFA has provided leadership and direction to holistic and risk specialist financial advisers through more than six decades of change, including FSR," Mr Klipin said. "We therefore have a very clear understanding of the profession and we believe the fundamental issue is consumer protection - consumers who engage an adviser working under an AFSL have rights and protection. Until this distinction is enshrined in law, those who do not act under a financial services licence will continue to operate and consumers who use their services will continue to be at risk."

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>

AFA President, Brad Fox said that in the interests of consumers, it is very important that members of the financial advice community's various professional associations are seen to be cooperative, supportive and respectful of each other in raising public perception around financial advice. “It is a combination of behaviour and education that will change consumer perception, not a sticker or badge that says you belong to one association or another," Fox said.

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>

"To see that consumers are better served, we believe the focus should firstly be on ensuring sensible FOFA outcomes, rather than pursuing self interests," he said. "We can assure all consumers and interested parties that AFA Members are not operating in a moral and/or ethical vacuum and have continued to demonstrate outstanding professionalism and compassion for our clients for 65 years. We also confirm that the AFA will continue to represent the interests of all financial advice professionals where those interests are consistent with positive consumer outcomes.”</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>]]></content:encoded>
