		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Financial planning]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-planning-2"><![CDATA[Financial planning]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[financial services]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-services"><![CDATA[financial services]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="investment-strategy"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Thought Leadership]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="thought-leadership"><![CDATA[Thought Leadership]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?p=7817</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<ul>
	<li><strong>Aii Energy ETF includes all key energy stocks listed on ASX; saves investors time and energy trying to pick winners
</strong></li>
	<li><strong>Provides investors with the ability to take a macro approach to investing by taking a view on the energy sector and benefiting from the sector bias</strong></li>
</ul>
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
Australian-owned sector ETF provider, Australian Index Investments (Aii), believes that with the increase in energy costs worldwide that it might be time for investors to tilt their portfolios towards this growth sector.

<span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span>
“There are some views in the marketplace that oil stock prices have not yet translated into more widespread gains on the ASX, and importantly, with a basic underlying energy shortage, global demand from economic hotspots like China and India, along with civil unrest in other developing economies suggests that triple digit, long-term oil prices are here to stay,” said Annmaree Varelas, CEO of Aii.

<span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span>

“The Aii Energy ETF is based on an index of 22 stocks including oil majors such as Woodside Petroleum, Origin Energy, Santos and Oil Search.  Interestingly, the sector ETF does not just include oil producers but also offers exposure to explorers and service companies supplying the energy industry,” said Ms Varelas.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">X </span>

The beauty of investing in a sector ETF is that investors can take a macro view on the energy sector and not worry about trying to pick winners and more importantly, avoiding the losers.

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
“On average, over 80% of the return that the investor generally receives for a stock comes from general market and sector returns, and only 10%-20% of the return actually comes from the attractiveness of the stock. As such, if you can take a macro approach to investing by getting the market and sector right, then you are 80% of the way there,” said Ms Varelas.
<h3><strong> E<strong>nergy Sector Outperforms</strong></strong></h3>
<h3><strong> ﻿</strong></h3>
<strong><a rel="attachment wp-att-7818" href="http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/triple-digit-oil-prices-are-here-to-stay-%e2%80%93-energy-sector-to-benefit/ai-graph/"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-7818" title="Ai graph" src="http://www.adviservoice.com/dev/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/Ai-graph.png" alt="" width="576" height="300" /></a></strong>

Source: Iress complied by Australian Index Investments

<strong>Product Information</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Aii S&amp;P/ASX 200 Energy ETF</li>
	<li>ASX Code: ENY</li>
	<li>MER: 0.43%</li>
	<li>Number of holdings: 22</li>
	<li>Top 10 holdings: Woodside, Origin, Santos, Oil Search,      Worley Parsons, Paladin Energy, Riverdale Mining, Caltex, Whitehaven Coal,      Aquila Resources</li>
</ul>
<strong><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></strong>

The current range of <strong>Aii Sector ETFs</strong> includes:

<a rel="attachment wp-att-7821" href="http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/triple-digit-oil-prices-are-here-to-stay-%e2%80%93-energy-sector-to-benefit/ai-chart/"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-7821" title="Ai chart" src="http://www.adviservoice.com/dev/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/Ai-chart.png" alt="" width="512" height="300" /></a>

		<item>
		<title>Are domestic Covered Bonds the solution for banks and investors? </title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/are-domestic-covered-bonds-the-solution-for-banks-and-investors/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 20 Apr 2011 23:07:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[assets]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="assets"><![CDATA[assets]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[debt]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="debt"><![CDATA[debt]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[financial advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-advisers"><![CDATA[financial advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Financial planners]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-planners"><![CDATA[Financial planners]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Financial planning]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-planning-2"><![CDATA[Financial planning]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[financial services]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-services"><![CDATA[financial services]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[From the Source]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="from-the-source"><![CDATA[From the Source]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Fund Management]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="fund-management"><![CDATA[Fund Management]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[mortgage security]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mortgage-security"><![CDATA[mortgage security]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[regulation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="regulation"><![CDATA[regulation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[securities]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="securities"><![CDATA[securities]]></category>

		<category domain="source" nicename="tyndall-investments"><![CDATA[Tyndall Investments]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?p=7814</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[While Covered Bonds may offer an appealing funding option for banks and give investors alternatives, there are risks entailed, according to Tyndall’s latest research White Paper, “Are Covered Bonds the solution?"

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>The suggestion to introduce domestic Covered Bonds was contained in the Federal Government’s proposals for a “Competitive and Sustainable Banking System”.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">X
</span>The Federal Government then released an Exposure Draft on Covered Bonds legislation in March 2011.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">X
</span>Comments on the draft are due by 22 April 2011 before the Bill in its final form is tabled in Parliament.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">X
</span>Introducing Covered Bonds form part of a strategy to: create an additional AAA-rated funding source; lower bank funding costs; create competition in the bank lending market; and address the issue of the liquid assets requirement in Basel III.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">X
</span>A Covered Bond is a security issued by a bank with assets (usually mortgages, but sometimes other loans) assigned to provide security for the debt.  Typically the size of the asset pool (or ‘cover pool’) is larger than the bond issue.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">X
</span>As the Tyndall paper, co-authored by John Sorrell, head of credit at Tyndall Investments, and senior credit analyst Ileria Chan, explains, unlike a residential mortgage-backed security (RMBS), Covered Bond cashflows are funded by the financial institution and not by the cashflows of the pool of assets.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">X
</span>Thus a Covered Bond has regular payments and no prepayment, so that it resembles a traditional bond issue.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>Dr Sorrell says that it is possible we could see domestic Covered Bonds traded before the end of 2011.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>“They offer investors further high-quality credit investments but investors must remember that they are still bank debt and not a direct substitute for government-guaranteed bank debt.

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
“Indeed, despite the government’s intention, while the introduction of Covered Bonds in Australia is a strong positive for the major banks, they may weaken, rather than enhance, competition in the banking sector and could further widen the funding access gap between the major and the second tier banks.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
“Covered Bonds may also cause consequences for senior debt holders and bank depositors leading to potential conflicts and regulatory risk,” he said.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
The Tyndall paper notes that the size of the Australian Covered Bond market will be constrained by investors’ existing senior debt exposures, so for most Australian portfolios, offshore issues of Covered Bonds available domestically will probably still be of more interest.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
Nevertheless, Dr Sorrell said that the Tyndall fixed interest team will itself consider Covered Bonds as a potential sector for investment, depending upon pricing and liquidity, and adding Covered Bonds to the total fund exposure to each issuer.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span>
The Tyndall White Paper points out that Australia is one of the last developed countries to introduce Covered Bonds, and considers why they are now being introduced, who will buy them, and what the risks are.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
Co-author Ileria Chan says that unless controlled, Covered Bonds could lead to conflict and regulatory risk for senior debt and depositors.

“They do have some attractive risk features – perhaps the most important for investors is the dual recourse to the bank and to the collateral, while senior bank investors can only claim on the bank and RMBS investors can only claim on the collateral. This is an important risk enhancement but comes at a price in yield to investors.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
“Also, as the assets used to provide the cover must be assigned unambiguously to the Covered Bond issue it does result in a reduction to the amount of assets available to other unsecured lenders, including depositors.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
“In addition, risks are not completely removed since the assets are correlated with the issuer and are long-dated illiquid assets,” Ms Chan said.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>Dr Sorrell added that being able to issue Covered Bonds does provide an attractive alternative funding option in a bank’s funding mix – but perhaps not as attractive as might at first appear and they may impact on lower-rated entities’ ability to compete.

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
“In Europe Covered Bonds form a deep and mature market. The European experience showed that they were one of the first asset classes to recover and provide liquidity during the credit crisis.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
“Canadian investors have preferred senior debt to Covered Bonds for their banks and Canadian banks have issued their Covered Bonds outside their borders.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
“Australian banks may, likewise, find more acceptance for their Covered Bond issues offshore than they will domestically, as they could cannibalise their Australian dollar senior debt programs,” he says.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
Ms Chan believes that overall they have a place for investors, but the risks need to be understood and priced appropriately.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
“Covered Bonds are well suited to the needs of investors who can only invest in AAA-rated securities (i.e. sovereign funds) or have a minimum allocation to AAA-rated assets. They potentially also offer an alternative to supras or government guaranteed debt.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
“For investors who are able to invest in senior bank paper and have comfort with the issuer’s name, Covered Bonds may be less appealing since they can use up limits on exposures to these names with lower yielding investments,” she said.

<a href="http://www.tyndall.com.au/dirt/tyndall/tyndallpublishv3.nsf/AttachmentsByTitle/Research+Paper+-+Covered+bonds+April+11/$FILE/Covered_Bonds_April_2011_Final.pdf">Click to open a full copy of the report</a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Is it time for an equities comeback?</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/is-it-time-for-an-equities-comeback/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 27 Apr 2011 00:17:05 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Australian dollar]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="australian-dollar"><![CDATA[Australian dollar]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[banks. investment]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="banks-investment"><![CDATA[banks. investment]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[business growth]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="business-growth-2"><![CDATA[business growth]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[consumer spending]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="consumer-spending"><![CDATA[consumer spending]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Emerging Markets]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="emerging-markets"><![CDATA[Emerging Markets]]></category>

		<category domain="source" nicename="fil-investment-management-australia-limited"><![CDATA[FIL Investment Management (Australia) Limited]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[financial advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-advisers"><![CDATA[financial advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Financial planning]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-planning-2"><![CDATA[Financial planning]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[global markets]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="global-markets"><![CDATA[global markets]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="investment-strategy"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Managers Corner]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="managers-corner"><![CDATA[Managers Corner]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[mining stocks]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="mining-stocks"><![CDATA[mining stocks]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[share market]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="share-market"><![CDATA[share market]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?p=7883</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<blockquote>Paul Taylor, Head of Australian Equities at Fidelity and Portfolio Manager of the Fidelity Australian Equities Fund, provides his outlook for the Australian stock market and why the market is presenting so many opportunities for stock pickers.</blockquote>
It could be a good time to buy Australian equities, according to one of the country’s best performing fund managers.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span><strong>Where do you see the Australian market heading for the rest of 2011?</strong>

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>“While we are positive on the outlook for the Australian market in 2011, there are some black macro clouds hanging about. One is the European sovereign debt crisis, which began as concerns around Greece, spread to Ireland and could engulf Portugal and Spain. Another is the instability or geopolitical risk in the Middle  East and north Africa that is boosting oil prices. A third is that the Chinese government is trying to slow the country’s economic growth to control inflation. Then there are the repercussions from Japan’s earthquake. Lastly, there is still a question mark over the US economy even though many economic indicators, from retail sales to production, are improving.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>“But when we look through these clouds we see a lot of positive signs within the Australia stock market. The market is trading cheaply on a 12-times price-to-earnings ratio, which is below the historical average of over 16-times. It is offering a dividend yield of about 4% to 5%, which is historically attractive. Australian companies are in good shape. They have repaired their balance sheets; in fact, some have built up such large cash reserves you could say they have lazy balance sheets. The Australian economy is in relatively good shape.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>“At a stock level, we are seeing some exciting opportunities – some great companies are trading at cheap prices.”
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span><strong>What do you see as the main themes that will surface in the market in the next 12 months?
</strong><span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>“Over the next 12 months we are likely to see the continuing theme of a two-speed economy; a strong resources sector but also a strong Australian dollar and higher interest rates with their negative consequences for other segments of the economy. We could also see further merger and acquisition activity as companies with strong cash flows and balance sheets identify value in the market and potentially look for more growth opportunities. This could be both onshore and offshore activity.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>“The significant growth in smart phones, tablets, mobile telecommunications, online retailing and online media distribution is also likely to be a growing theme in the market over the next year and beyond with implications across multiple sectors.”
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span><strong>What are your top overweight holdings and why?
</strong><span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>“Key sector overweights for the portfolio are the industrials, healthcare, materials and energy sector but these outcomes are built from the bottom up. So what we're seeing in those different sectors are good companies at bargain prices. We think in this environment you want to be focused on pricing power; you want to be focused on the growth of the company.

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>“What we've seen generally is that the valuation of the whole market has gone down based on these big macro fears, but the market is not discriminating between companies. That’s why we are seeing great stock-selection opportunities. When the whole market is priced at a lower level, there's a great opportunity to pick up high-quality, high-growth companies on cheap valuations. And that’s what we have been doing across sectors.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>“In terms of sectors, mining services and engineering firms should benefit from the significant investment planned in major resource and infrastructure projects. This strong demand should lead to an improvement in contract terms like a move to a cost-plus basis and higher charge-out rates. Healthcare should see strong structural growth and should be relatively unaffected by the rising interest-rate environment. Within healthcare, I like the industry leaders and those stocks benefiting from structural growth themes.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>“If I look at some of the key overweight stocks positions in the Fund – Rio Tinto, Wesfarmers, MAp, Commonwealth Bank, ANZ and Oil Search – they are there because we think they are good companies with solid balance sheets and strong growth opportunities that are attractively valued.”
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span><strong>What are your views on material stocks?
</strong><span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>“Within the mining sector, we prefer the big-cap miners over the smaller miners. We see the big miners as great investment opportunities at the moment.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>“Right now all the miners – big and small – are trading on similar multiples, which is unusual. History tells us that the big miners such as Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton should trade at significant premiums to the small-cap miners because they have diversified earnings streams and quality management, are proven operators and own the tier-one assets – the low-cost, long-life mines.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>They should trade at a premium to the small-cap miners. But when commodity prices are rising, the market generally gets excited about small-cap miners.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>“The fact that all miners are trading on similar valuations opens up a fantastic opportunity to invest in the big miners because that's where the value is. To us, the great opportunity is Rio Tinto. On top of having the low-cost, long-life mines, Rio Tinto is trading at a valuation discount to BHP Billiton. So within the mining sector, Rio Tinto to us is the standout investment.”
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span><strong>What are your views on the banks?
</strong><span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>“Australian banks are reasonably valued at the moment. They are offering a good dividend yield. While their lending growth is slowing, their margins are improving. So from a sector point of view, I think banks are reasonable investments at the moment.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>“Within the banking sector, our preferences are for Commonwealth Bank and ANZ. We think these two banks are the best positioned because they have the best growth opportunities and have the lowest-cost funding.”
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span><strong>What do you think are the key risks for the next 12 months?
</strong><span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>“There are probably a few key risks for the Australian market over the next 12 months, the first of which is interest rates. The market still expects the Reserve Bank to boost interest rates in the second half of 2011. A cash rate at 5.25% from 4.75% now could add to pressure in the consumer-discretionary, in the household-spending, sector.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>“The second key risk is China. Chinese authorities are trying to slow economic growth to about 7% to 8% a year, which is still high by world standards. The question if they succeed is: are the Chinese still going to buy commodities at the same rate?
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>“Another risk is whether a destabilising macro issue eventuates. In Europe, people are nervous about Portugal and they're saying if there's an issue with Portugal it could spread to Spain. These risks are likely to hang over the market at least for 2011.”
<div class="disclaimer">This document is issued by FIL Investment Management (Australia) Limited ABN 34 006 773 575, AFSL No. 237865 (“Fidelity Australia”).  Fidelity Australia is a member of the FIL Limited group of companies commonly known as Fidelity International. Prior to making an investment decision, retail investors should seek advice from their financial advisers. Investors should also obtain and consider the Product Disclosure Statements (“PDS”) for any Fidelity fund mentioned in this document. The PDS is available at www.fidelity.com.au. This document may include general commentary on market activity, sector trends or other broad-based economic or political conditions that should not be taken as investment advice. Information stated herein about specific securities is subject to change. Any reference to specific securities should not be taken as a recommendation to buy, sell or hold these securities. While the information contained in this document has been prepared with reasonable care, no responsibility or liability is accepted for any errors or omissions or misstatements however caused. The document may not be reproduced or transmitted without prior written permission of Fidelity Australia. Investments in overseas markets can be affected by currency exchange and this may affect the value of an investment. Investments in small and emerging markets can be more volatile than investments in developed markets. The issuer of Fidelity’s managed investment schemes is Perpetual Trust Services Limited (“Perpetual”) ABN 48 000 142 049. Perpetual is not the publisher of this document and takes no responsibility for its content. Reference to ($) are in Australian dollars unless stated otherwise. © 2011 FIL Investment Management (Australia) Limited.  Fidelity, Fidelity International and the Fidelity International and Pyramid logos are trademarks of FIL Limited.</div>]]></content:encoded>

		<title>AXA Financial Advice Network announces national adviser of the year</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/axa-financial-advice-network-announces-national-adviser-of-the-year/</link>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?p=7839</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div id="_mcePaste">AXA’s Financial Advice Network has announced the winner of its national annual adviser award, the Gerald Lippman Perpetual Trophy. This year’s winner is Paul Aspros of PSK Financial Services</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">“This award is presented to the most outstanding adviser who has contributed not only to the AXA network, but to their local and wider community, as well as the profession”, said Andrew Waddell, AXA Financial Advice Network’s General Manager.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>“Each year we assess professional and practice development, feedback from colleagues and the contributions made by the individual, and this year Paul Aspros certainly stood out as someone who strives to make a difference in people’s lives.”</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">“This is the highest honour AXA Financial Advice Network can bestow on one of its advisers,” he said.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Mr Aspros is the practice principle of Sydney based PSK Financial Services, licensed with Charter Financial Planning. Over the years Paul has led the practice through significant growth, and successfully incorporated a number of smaller practices through their business model to become the network’s largest advice business. He was the previous chairman of the Authorised Representatives’ Association (ARA) and is highly respected within AXA’s Financial Advice Network.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">“To be recognised by your peers is always a great honour. I consider many of my fellow advisers as great friends and role models”.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;"> </span>Mr Aspros also acknowledged there were some challenges ahead for the wider industry.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">“While there is some uncertainty as we look ahead, uncertainty brings with it opportunity, and I am looking forward to seeing advisers take advantage of these opportunities with the support of AMP,” he said.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Away from the office, Aspros is the manager of the Sydney University Football Club under 15’s team and recently took a team of young footballers on an overseas tour of Spain. He has also been instrumental in organising and running highly successful charity events for the Heart and Starlight Foundations.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;"> </span>In 2010 he was actively involved in the development of the Breast Cancer Awareness Workshop and the PSK Prostate Cancer Awareness Workshop that provided educational forums to assist with the prevention or early detection of these diseases.</div>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>BetaShares Capital Ltd: Australia sets the standard in ETF regulation</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/betashares-capital-ltd-australia-sets-the-standard-in-etf-regulation/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 27 Apr 2011 05:38:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category><![CDATA[Best Practice]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="best-practice"><![CDATA[Best Practice]]></category>

		<category domain="source" nicename="betashares-capital-limited"><![CDATA[BetaShares Capital Limited]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[counterparty]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="counterparty"><![CDATA[counterparty]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[financial advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-advisers"><![CDATA[financial advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Financial planning]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-planning-2"><![CDATA[Financial planning]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Fund Management]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="fund-management"><![CDATA[Fund Management]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[global markets]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="global-markets"><![CDATA[global markets]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="investment-strategy"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[investors]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="investors"><![CDATA[investors]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[reform]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="reform"><![CDATA[reform]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[regulation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="regulation"><![CDATA[regulation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[synthetic ETFs]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="synthetic-etfs"><![CDATA[synthetic ETFs]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?p=7843</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div id="_mcePaste">
<div id="_mcePaste">BetaShares Capital Ltd (BetaShares), one of Australia’s leading exchange traded fund (ETF) providers, says Australia is leading the way with best practice standards for regulating ETFs that are designed to ensure Australia avoids issues raised in the recent Bank for International Settlements (BIS) paper on the risk of ETFs.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>Some of the key issues highlighted in the BIS paper relate to the quality and liquidity of physical assets underlying synthetic ETFs and motivations that may arise when the ETF issuer is a related party to the investment bank that is the swap counterparty.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">BetaShares is the issuer of both physical replication and synthetic replication ETFs in Australia.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Drew Corbett, Head of Investment Strategy &amp; Distribution at BetaShares said the paper has highlighted some important issues relating to overseas synthetic ETFs that were addressed by the Australian regulators prior to synthetic ETFs being introduced in Australia.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">“In the process of launching our synthetic ETFs in December 2010, we worked collaboratively with ASIC and ASX who set the standard in synthetic ETF regulation. ASIC and the ASX have been one step ahead in relation to the key issues raised in the BIS paper and should be complimented for adopting world’s best practice on ETF regulation. The rest of the world should be following Australia’s lead,” Mr Corbett said.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">The guidelines developed by the Australian regulators included local swap-enhanced ETFs being allowed a maximum counterparty exposure of 10% and a requirement for the underlying assets held by the ETF to be consistent with the investment objective of the fund.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">As such, the basket of assets which make up BetaShares ETFs can only be ASX300 stocks related to the index being tracked or cash as outlined in the product disclosure statement. In addition, since inception, any counterparty exposure in BetaShares synthetic ETFs has been less than 0.5% of the NAV as part of its stricter self-imposed standards.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">BetaShares as the responsible entity enters into arms-length agreements with swap counterparties that are not related entities, ensuring that BetaShares always acts in the best interests of the ETF investors. Similarly, the choice of physical assets that are owned by BetaShares ETFs is only influenced by BetaShares’ fiduciary duties to its unitholders.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">“BetaShares looked at synthetic ETFs overseas and wanted to provide the benefits of more accurate tracking, lower costs and ultimately improved liquidity to reduce costs for investors, but without some of the less desirable structural elements that are present in foreign markets.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
</div>
<div id="_mcePaste">We firmly believe that investors should expect uncompromised transparency in ETFs. As firm, we are committed to upholding this principle, both in respect of our physical replication ETFs as well as our synthetic ETFs,” he said.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">For example, by visiting the BetaShares website, investors can see the exact basket of shares which are held by BetaShares synthetic ETFs.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">“Although there may be some undesirable practices occurring in overseas ETF markets, believe BetaShares and Australian regulators are lifting the standards by which all synthetic ETF issuers should be assessed. We believe the evolution of ETFs to a synthetic structure can provide advantages which are unavailable from physical replication alone and will continue to work with regulators to ensure they remain the robust structures that ETF investors expect,” Mr Corbett concluded.</div>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Risking Everything: AFA Calls on Minister Shorten to Do the Maths</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/risking-everything-afa-calls-on-minister-shorten-to-do-the-maths/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 27 Apr 2011 06:00:16 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[AFA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="afa"><![CDATA[AFA]]></category>

		<category domain="source" nicename="afa-association-of-financial-advisers"><![CDATA[AFA - Association of Financial Advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[consumers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="consumers"><![CDATA[consumers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[financial advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-advisers"><![CDATA[financial advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Financial planners]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-planners"><![CDATA[Financial planners]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Financial planning]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-planning-2"><![CDATA[Financial planning]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[financial services]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-services"><![CDATA[financial services]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Industry Bodies]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="investment-strategy"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[self-managed superannuation funds]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="self-managed-superannuation-funds"><![CDATA[self-managed superannuation funds]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[superannuation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="superannuation-2"><![CDATA[superannuation]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?p=7847</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<blockquote>New consumer research reveals tampering with life insurance commissions could mean consumers risk everything
<span style="color: #ffffff;"><em>
</em></span></blockquote>
Initial findings from <em>Risking</em> <em>Everything</em> – the Association of Financial Advisers (AFA)’s third tranche of research - reveal that many Australians would not seek life insurance advice if forced to pay for it via an upfront fee rather than via commissions. They also fear losing affordable access to advice if opt-in becomes a reality.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>The research, commissioned by the AFA; conducted by CoreData and sponsored by AIA Australia, surveyed corporate super and life insurance clients. AFA CEO Richard Klipin said the findings reveal that people who use a financial adviser for their life insurance needs are more likely to have appropriate cover; be confident they understand what type and how much life insurance they need and feel comfortable they have sufficient cover.  “Disturbingly however, many would not pay for it if commissions are abolished,” he said.

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>

Key findings revealed that:
<ul>
	<li>The majority of people who have used a corporate super adviser would not be likely to pay upfront fees for financial advice if it was not part of their corporate super fund offer (56.0%).</li>
	<li>A commission paid by the insurance provider is both the most common (40.0%) and preferred (32.6%) payment method of those who receive advice on their life insurance.</li>
	<li>Two in five of those who are not currently paying upfront fees for advice and didn’t list it as their preferred method would not be willing to do so, even if it was the only option (40.5%).</li>
	<li>This implies that some of the few people actually receiving life insurance advice in today’s environment would exit the market if forced to pay a fee-for-service.</li>
	<li>The major reason those with life insurance but without an adviser have not sought advice to manage their life insurance needs is an aversion to paying fees (44.0%).</li>
</ul>
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
The findings also revealed some horrifying statistics around opt-in.
<ul>
	<li>Three in five members (61.4%) who have utilised the services of a corporate super adviser claim that the possibility of losing these services in an opt-in environment is of great concern to them compared to only 17.3% who indicate this is of no concern.</li>
	<li>Employers express even greater concern about the potential consequences of opt-in than members with some 78.5% indicating the legislation is of great concern.</li>
	<li>Employers say the removal of corporate super services under opt-in could reduce benefits for employees and put members at risk of making poor decisions around their super and finances.</li>
</ul>
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
“Ultimately what these findings tell us is that the proposed FOFA reforms around the possible banning of commissions on risk products and opt-in will, if implemented, have a devastating effect on ordinary Australians,” Mr Klipin said. “Fewer would get advice and even fewer would have life insurance. Without insurance, families would be left unprotected. If a breadwinner dies or cannot work as a result of illness or injury, the family risks losing everything.”

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>

Mr Klipin said in light of the evidence, it’s time for the Government to stop grandstanding and start thinking about adviser remuneration from a family-in-the-street perspective.

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
“Advisers, who do a great deal of good work for their clients – not only in assessing their needs but also handholding them when life deals them devastating blows – need to be paid.  They have no problem charging fees for their services; it’s every day Australians, trying to balance ever-tightening household budgets that have a problem paying them.”

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
AIA Australia’s Head of Adviser Services, Pina Sciarrone, said financial advisers play a vital role in narrowing the under-insurance gap. “Advisers help consumers understand what type of insurance they need, how much they need and the best way to purchase it – either inside or outside their super funds,” she said. “If people can’t afford to access that advice, they are likely to have seriously inadequate levels of cover or, worse still, no cover at all.”

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>

Mr Klipin urged Minister for Financial Services and Superannuation, Bill Shorten to take a long hard look at the figures around the financial impact of underinsurance on families, communities and the Australian economy before banning commissions.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>

“Families impacted by the early death, disablement or illness of a breadwinner often can't service their own debt,” Mr Klipin argued. “They not only risk losing their homes, but ultimately place a burden on the public purse.  It’s time Mr Shorten did the maths."
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>

<span>Underinsurance Crisis – Some Statistics from the Research</span>
<ul>
	<li>Around half of respondents have life insurance (52.0%).</li>
	<li>Two in five (43.5%) say they are not likely to ever take out insurance.</li>
	<li>The average person with life insurance is underinsured. Across all wealth segments, the average self-reported level of cover is just 5x earnings – half of what is recommended by Rice Warner.</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>FPA to examine fine detail of FoFA reform package</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/fpa-to-examine-fine-detail-of-fofa-reform-package/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 27 Apr 2011 23:49:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[consumers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="consumers"><![CDATA[consumers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-advisers"><![CDATA[financial advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Financial planners]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-planners"><![CDATA[Financial planners]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[financial services]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-services"><![CDATA[financial services]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[FoFA reforms]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="fofa-reforms"><![CDATA[FoFA reforms]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[FPA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="fpa"><![CDATA[FPA]]></category>

		<category domain="source" nicename="fpa-financial-planning-association"><![CDATA[FPA - Financial Planning Association]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Fund Management]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="fund-management"><![CDATA[Fund Management]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="regulation"><![CDATA[regulation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[superannuation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="superannuation-2"><![CDATA[superannuation]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?p=7873</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>Consumers, professionals deserve absolute clarity on full impact of Future of Financial Advice (FoFA) reforms</h2>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">The Financial Planning Association (FPA) says a detailed examination of the Future of Financial Advice (FoFA) reforms announced today by the Minister for Financial Services, Bill Shorten, is required to understand how the package will deliver improved outcomes for consumers and FPA member professionals.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">The FPA is specifically concerned about banning risk insurance commissions inside superannuation and legislating opt-in by clients every two years, and will continue its consultation with Government on these key aspects of the FoFA package.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">However, FPA CEO Mark Rantall said the decision to look at amending the original proposed FoFA reforms in regard to the expansion of intra-fund advice and the best interests duty, will apply welcome consumer protection measures in a consistent manner across the industry.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">“The FPA has long been calling for further initiatives to improve access and affordability of financial advice to more Australians and supports the announcement to adopt a uniform and consistent approach so that all financial planners have the ability to provide scalable advice to more Australians,” Mr Rantall said.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">The FPA has worked closely with Government to ensure the best outcome for the profession, and consumers, and will continue to do so as the full detail of the proposals is understood.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">“We acknowledge the consultation undertaken by the Government and Treasury and are pleased to see a number of the FPA’s recommendations included in the FoFA reforms announced today.”</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Specific reforms included:</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">
<ul>
	<li>The introduction of scaled advice including the decision to remove the barriers to the provision of low-cost simple advice to improve access for all consumers on all financial matters (not just superannuation and expanded to Financial Planners).</li>
	<li>Consideration of the removal of the class-order relief for superannuation trustees which will ensure consumer protection measures are adhered to by all advice providers.</li>
	<li>Amending the client renewal opt-in requirement to two years. This is not our preferred outcome and the FPA does not believe that opt-in should be legislated, but awaits the detail in the draft legislation to understand how concerns about administration, penalties and consumer protection are addressed.</li>
	<li>Recognition that the focus of the best interest duty should be on how a person has acted in providing the advice rather than the outcome</li>
	<li>Consideration of the extent of the best interest duty applying to the providing entity (licensee)</li>
	<li>A prospective ban on insurance commissions inside superannuation. The FPA continues to support insurance commissions until a valid alternative remuneration structure is available. Whilst we are pleased that this has not extended to insurance commissions outside Superannuation, we believe insurance commissions across the sector should be maintained.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">The FPA also acknowledges the Minister’s agreement to consider the FPA’s proposal raised during the FoFA consultations, to enshrine the term financial planner in law and the vital role this will play in the protection of consumers and the evolution of the financial planning profession.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">“Now that we have further details of the FoFA reform measures we turn our attention to the draft legislation and the detail that will underpin these reforms,” Mr Rantall said.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">“Getting the detail right will have a significant impact on the success of the reforms and the FPA looks forward to providing input in this next stage.”</div>]]></content:encoded>

							</item>
		<item>
		<title>AMP responds to Future of Financial Advice reforms</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/amp-responds-to-future-of-financial-advice-reforms/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 28 Apr 2011 00:14:46 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="source" nicename="amp-limited"><![CDATA[AMP Limited]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[consumers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="consumers"><![CDATA[consumers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[financial advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-advisers"><![CDATA[financial advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Financial planners]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-planners"><![CDATA[Financial planners]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Financial planning]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-planning-2"><![CDATA[Financial planning]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[financial services]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-services"><![CDATA[financial services]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[From the Source]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="from-the-source"><![CDATA[From the Source]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[insurance]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="insurance"><![CDATA[insurance]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="investment-strategy"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[reform]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="reform"><![CDATA[reform]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[regulation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="regulation"><![CDATA[regulation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[superannuation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="superannuation-2"><![CDATA[superannuation]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?p=7878</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div id="_mcePaste">AMP has announced its support of the Government’s intention to introduce a fiduciary-like obligation on all financial planners and advisers across the industry, requiring them to put their clients’ interests first.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">AMP Financial Services Managing Director Craig Meller said: “At AMP and AXA, financial advice is at the heart of what we do, and we have long believed there is no question that the pre-eminent responsibility of financial planners and advisers should be to act in their clients’ best interests.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">“Quality financial advice plays an important role in helping Australians achieve their goals in life, including enjoying a comfortable retirement and ensuring adequate insurance protection in the event things go wrong.  The legal obligation, across the industry, to act in a client’s best interest is consistent with the standards expected of other professions and will play an important role in enhancing consumer confidence in the financial advice profession,“ said Mr Meller.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">“This policy initiative will provide consumers with significant protection from any perceived conflict of interest or inappropriate product recommendations,” said Mr Meller.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Both AMP and AXA removed in-built commissions from new superannuation, pension and investment business in mid 2010.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">However, Mr Meller said the Government’s proposal to ban commissions on life insurance paid for within superannuation, including income protection and disability cover, goes too far and it is not clear what problem is being addressed.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">“The proposal to ban commissions on life insurance within superannuation is ineffective public policy because it will inevitably exacerbate Australians’ chronic level of underinsurance.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">“Without the encouragement and support of a financial planner many people do not appreciate the necessity to arrange adequate insurance.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">“Arranging insurance can be complex and confronting for many people and financial planners make it easy for people to get the cover they need.  In addition, society as a whole benefits from people taking steps to protect themselves financially from unforseen circumstances.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">“An unintended consequence of this policy is likely to be the transfer of a greater burden to taxpayers who will be required to meet the social costs of underinsurance.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">“An alternative would be to consider policy initiatives that would increase Australians overall level of insurance cover,” said Mr Meller.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Today’s announcement also included a range of proposals where AMP is yet to develop a detailed understanding of the policies and their impacts.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">AMP looks forward to continuing working and consulting with the Government and the Opposition as the new policy proposals announced today go through the legislative review process.</div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>AFA: FOFA hangs consumers out to dry</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/afa-fofa-hangs-consumers-out-to-dry/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 28 Apr 2011 00:36:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[AFA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="afa"><![CDATA[AFA]]></category>

		<category domain="source" nicename="afa-association-of-financial-advisers"><![CDATA[AFA - Association of Financial Advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Financial planners]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-planners"><![CDATA[Financial planners]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Financial planning]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-planning-2"><![CDATA[Financial planning]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[financial services]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-services"><![CDATA[financial services]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Fund Management]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="fund-management"><![CDATA[Fund Management]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Industry Bodies]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="industry-bodies"><![CDATA[Industry Bodies]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[insurance]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="insurance"><![CDATA[insurance]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="investment-strategy"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[reform]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="reform"><![CDATA[reform]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[regulation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="regulation"><![CDATA[regulation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[self-managed superannuation funds]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="self-managed-superannuation-funds"><![CDATA[self-managed superannuation funds]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[superannuation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="superannuation-2"><![CDATA[superannuation]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?p=7863</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2><span style="font-weight: normal;">FOFA hijacked by the superannuation lobby</span></h2>
The Future of Financial Advice (FOFA) reform package announced this morning will impose higher costs on consumers, impede their access to advice, tie them up in red tape and create even greater confusion according to the Association of Financial Advisers (AFA).

“While we believe the original intent of FOFA was commendable, the execution is not,” AFA CEO, Richard Klipin said. “The FOFA rhetoric has not been matched with strategy and consumers have been hung out to dry.”
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
Mr Klipin said that the AFA is concerned that the real needs of consumers have fallen on deaf ears.  “While only two in 10 Australians currently get advice, we know from our consumer research that good advice gives people choices and leads to higher levels of savings, appropriate levels of  insurance and greater control of their future,” he said. “Under the announced reforms the number of people able to access advice is in danger of dropping to even fewer than two in 10.”
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
Mr Klipin said the AFA believes the FOFA agenda has been hijacked by the superannuation lobby movement at the expense of everyday Australians. “While it might be a victory for large superannuation funds and the superannuation lobby cheer squad, it is a dark day indeed for ordinary Australians and their ability to access affordable advice,” he said.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
<h3><span style="font-weight: normal;">The AFA’s Response to the Government’s Proposed Reforms</span>
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
Ban on Commissions on Risk Products within Superannuation</h3>
Mr Klipin said the Government’s intention to ban commissions on risk products within superannuation means consumers will have to fund the cost of advice upfront, out of their own pockets.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
“As our <em>Risking Everything</em> research revealed, a ban on commissions will mean people won’t access advice,” he said. “We have said it before and we will say it again:  it is not advisers who object to charging fees, it is consumers who have a problem paying them.”
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
Mr Klipin also said the Government is well aware that the more tinkering that goes on with the superannuation system, the less confidence the community has in the future of super. “Forcing people to pay fees for insurance advice inside super will mean even fewer will have adequate levels of insurance,” he said. “In a country that is already grossly-underinsured and under-saved these changes will ultimately put a greater drain on the public purse.”
<strong><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
Opt In</strong>

On the issue of opt-in, Mr Klipin said that while a two-year period is a minor victory for common sense, the devil is in the detail. “If you read between the lines the two years becomes one year by stealth.  But whatever the period, we believe opt-in is bad policy. It devalues the long term nature of the relationships consumers have with their advisers and increases the adviser workload which, again, pushes up the cost of advice.”
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
Mr Klipin also argued that it is not the role of Government to dictate how consumers engage in their advice relationships.  “We do not need a return to the Nanny State – Australians are too smart for that.”

<strong><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
Product Failures or Advice Failures?
</strong> <span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
“What the Government has failed to realise is that many of the financial losses suffered by consumers in the past were the result of product rather than advice failures. None of the reforms put forward today address this,” said AFA President, Brad Fox

<strong><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
The Law of Unintended Consequences.</strong>

Mr Fox called on Minister for Financial Services and Superannuation, Bill Shorten to release the research that identifies the impacts of FOFA on the millions of consumers and thousands of advisers and their communities across the country.

“With such a substantive program of reform we expect to see the Government’s modelling on the impact of FOFA on:
<ul>
	<li>advice delivery</li>
	<li>costs of advice delivery</li>
	<li>small business valuations</li>
	<li>employment within the advice sector</li>
	<li>the viability of the non-institutional advice sector.”</li>
</ul>
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
Mr Fox said the AFA will continue to fight for what it believes is right for clients. “Financial advisers take on the role of providing leadership and direction to everyday Australians; they are at the heart of what we do,” he said.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span>
“We will continue to fight on their behalf until the FOFA recommendations are fully focussed on them and their ability to access personalised financial advice in a sensible, affordable manner.”]]></content:encoded>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="risk"><![CDATA[risk]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="strategic-asset-allocation"><![CDATA[strategic asset allocation]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?p=7890</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>Equities still offer better returns for the long term investor</h2>
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
Even when equity markets are weak, investors should still closely consider a long term investment in equities, according to recently-named Morningstar Fund Manager of the Year, Aviva Investors.

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>"Those who accept the temptation to flee from equities to supposedly 'safe havens' such as cash may miss out on the stronger long term gains that stock investments can offer. And it's at times such as the present when equities are flat and cash returns seem relatively strong that the temptation can be particularly strong," says Aviva Investors' Fund Manager, Glenn Hart.

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>To illustrate the case, Mr Hart points to a 15-year performance comparison between a $10,000 investment in Australian equities, one in bonds and one in cash. This shows that, in the timeframe concerned - between 1996 and 2011 - Australian equities have produced significantly higher returns than either cash or bonds.

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>"Yes, cash is virtually risk free however it also delivers a relatively modest return, especially once you factor in the eroding effect of inflation. Equities on the other hand while relatively high risk have the potential to generate much greater returns," Mr Hart said.

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>"Which type of investment will suit which type of investor will depend on the risk appetite and investment time horizon concerned, something I think we're all aware of. But it can be less easy to be clear sighted when there is a lot of noise in the market and the fear factor kicks in - something we are still seeing happening now."

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>According to Mr Hart, cash is certainly suitable for some investors - such as retirees or others with a short investment timeframe. However, for many others, he says, it's important not to throw out the baby with the bathwater and take a long term view

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>"While higher returns are not guaranteed with an equity investment, they are definitely possible and by taking a long term view of your investments, it is easier to look through periods of weakness and view them as temporary."

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>However, Mr Hart also counsels that diversification is crucial in any portfolio.

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>"If recent market events have taught us anything it is that true diversification is essential. That involves spreading your investments across not only different asset classes, but also different sectors and industries in order to lower your risk. Different companies will perform well or badly depending on market conditions. A robustly diversified portfolio that contains investments in a variety of companies operating in different sectors and industries can offer more stable returns.

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>"While the security of capital offered by cash investments can be attractive, if you have a medium to long term investment horizon, investing in cash does not make much sense financially. For the long term investor, far greater returns are potentially on offer by staying the course and investing in equity markets." Mr Hart said.
<div id="_mcePaste">
<div class="disclaimer"><span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>The above information is of a general nature and has been prepared without taking account of your individual investment objectives, financial situation or particular investment needs. It is not intended as financial advice to retail clients. Before making an investment decision, you should consider the appropriateness of the information, having regard to your objectives, financial situation and needs. We recommend you consult with your financial adviser, who can help you determine how best to achieve your financial goals and whether investing in a fund is appropriate for you.   Aviva Investors Australia Limited ABN 85 066 081 114. AFS Licence No. 234483. Level 28 Freshwater Place, 2 Southbank Boulevard, Southbank 3006 GPO Box 2007s, Melbourne 3001 Telephone: (03) 9220 0300 Facsimile: (03) 9220 0333 Email: investorservices.au@avivainvestors.com Website: www.avivainvestors.com.au Part of the international Aviva plc group. Disclaimer © 2011 Morningstar, Inc. All rights reserved. The data and content contained herein are not guaranteed to be accurate, complete or timely. Neither Morningstar, nor its affiliates nor their content providers will have any liability for use or distribution of any of this information. To the extent that any of the content above constitutes advice, it is general advice that has been prepared by Morningstar Australasia Pty Ltd ABN: 95 090 665 544, AFSL: 240892 (a subsidiary of Morningstar, Inc.), without reference to your objectives, financial situation or needs. Before acting on any advice, you should consider the appropriateness of the advice and we recommend you obtain financial, legal and taxation advice before making any financial investment decision. If applicable investors should obtain the relevant product disclosure stateme nt and consider it before making any decision to invest. Please refer to our Financial Services Guide (FSG) for more information at www.morningstar.com.au/fsg.pdf.</div>

		<title>SPAA positive on most FOFA reforms</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/spaa-positive-on-most-fofa-reforms/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 28 Apr 2011 04:19:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[commissions]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="commissions"><![CDATA[commissions]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Industry Bodies]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="industry-bodies"><![CDATA[Industry Bodies]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[investment]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="investment"><![CDATA[investment]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="investment-strategy"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[professional development]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="professional-development"><![CDATA[professional development]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[reform]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="reform"><![CDATA[reform]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[regulation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="regulation"><![CDATA[regulation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[retirement]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="retirement"><![CDATA[retirement]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[self-managed superannuation funds]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="self-managed-superannuation-funds"><![CDATA[self-managed superannuation funds]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[SPAA]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="spaa"><![CDATA[SPAA]]></category>

		<category domain="source" nicename="spaa-self-managed-superannuation-funds-professionals-association"><![CDATA[SPAA - Self Managed Superannuation Funds Professionals Association]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[superannuation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="superannuation-2"><![CDATA[superannuation]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?p=7937</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<blockquote>
<div id="_mcePaste">SPAA is pleased the Government is considering scaled advice to replace the accountants’ exemption but disappointed risk commissions have been dealt with separately inside and outside of super.</div></blockquote>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">
</span></div>
<div>The Self Managed Super Fund Professionals’ Association (SPAA) has today welcomed the announcement of the detail of the Federal Government’s Future of Financial Advice (FOFA) reforms which seek to improve the quality of financial advice for Australians, but has expressed concern about some measures which may prompt inappropriate selling practices or increase costs for investors.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
“The FoFA reforms represent an important step forward in improving quality of advice outcomes for all Australians,” said Andrea Slattery, CEO of SPAA.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
“Like all investors, Australians who manage their own retirement savings in self managed super funds stand to benefit from the initiatives the Government announced today.” The reforms follow extensive consultation with industry which SPAA has been involved in.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
“SPAA is particularly pleased the Government will consider a restricted (scaled) advice licence for accountants, previously exempted from the licensed regime, who advise self managed super fund investors as we have worked hard to progress this issue with the Government. This recognises that accountants who advise on self managed funds may not wish to provide recommendations to clients to purchase specific financial products. We look forward to working with them on the detail, particularly on the minimum competencies required to hold such a licence,” Mrs Slattery said.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
SPAA has pushed for scaled (limited) advice to be made available across the superannuation and financial services industry and is pleased that a level playing field is being created for this to occur.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
“SPAA is also pleased that the Government is considering revocation of the ASIC class order which currently allows infra fund advice in superannuation. We look forward to being involved in consultations on the potential extension of intra fund advice to transition to retirement pensions, Centrelink entitlements and retirement planning generally,” she said.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
“SPAA has strongly advocated the introduction of a prescribed statutory duty for advisers to act in the best interests of clients. We are pleased the Government has heeded our call that such a duty should be scalable to the clients’ needs and instructions. SPAA patron, the Hon Sir Anthony Mason, agrees it is imperative that any legislation has regard to the client’s instructions when providing advice in the best interests of the client. SPAA will be keenly involved in further discussions in the consultation process,” Mrs Slattery said.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
Mrs Slattery said SPAA is supportive of the ban on conflicted remuneration, including commissions and soft dollar benefits. However, SPAA is pleased to see that professional development activities will not fall under the ban on soft dollar benefits. This will lift standards of education of financial advisers.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
“However, SPAA is very concerned that the commission ban on insurance products which only applies in superannuation, may distort the market and encourage mis-selling practices by opportunistic intermediaries,” she said.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
SPAA is also disappointed that the Government has chosen to nominate an ‘opt in’ arrangement where clients must nominate to renew their relationship with their adviser every two years.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
“SPAA does not believe an opt-in arrangement is required for financial advice in SMSFs and believes the Government should wait to see what effect the banning of commissions and volume payment changes have on the market before considering the introduction of these measures,” Mrs Slattery said.</div>]]></content:encoded>
