		<item>
		<title>Count positive on and ready for FoFA changes</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/count-positive-on-and-ready-for-fofa-changes/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 28 Apr 2011 06:38:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[consumers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="consumers"><![CDATA[consumers]]></category>

		<category domain="source" nicename="count-financial-limited"><![CDATA[Count Financial Limited]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[financial advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-advisers"><![CDATA[financial advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Financial planners]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-planners"><![CDATA[Financial planners]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Financial planning]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-planning-2"><![CDATA[Financial planning]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[financial services]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-services"><![CDATA[financial services]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[FoFA reforms]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="fofa-reforms"><![CDATA[FoFA reforms]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[From the Source]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="from-the-source"><![CDATA[From the Source]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Fund Management]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="fund-management"><![CDATA[Fund Management]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="investment-strategy"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[reform]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="reform"><![CDATA[reform]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[regulation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="regulation"><![CDATA[regulation]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?p=7958</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div id="_mcePaste">Leading accountant-based financial planning network Count Financial Limited (Count) said today it is well positioned with regards to the Future of Financial Advice (FOFA) reforms. Given the professional background of its accountant advisers, Count is a strong advocate of quality financial advice.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>Count also stands ready to implement a business strategy to respond to and capitalise on the reforms, including those relating to volume related payments.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">"Most changes announced today were expected and Count has been preparing for them for at least 12 months," said Andrew Gale, Count CEO.  "As one of the largest accountancy based networks of financial advisers, Count is well positioned to implement a growth strategy to capitalise on the opportunities offered. The reforms are likely to have a consolidation impact on the industry of which Count should be a beneficiary."</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Mr Gale noted that the reforms ban volume-related payments to licensees from July 1, 2012 but it is understood that grandfathering arrangements apply up to that time.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">"We believe the changes to volume payments are likely to favour larger organisations with robust risk management and sound capital capabilities, such as Count. It is expected that Count's operating margins will be resilient with these changes," Mr Gale said.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">"Count already operates a business model which does not conflict financial advice. However, as we have previously foreshadowed, we will likely look to change our business model to align with the new regulatory environment. This includes a range of outcomes in relation to platform offerings and restructuring as required, including "manufacturer" options and multi-manager/fund of fund offerings to help to safeguard against Count's share of "value chain" being adversely affected," Mr Gale said. He noted that Count is well advanced in its preparations for this scenario.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Mr Gale expressed concern that the Government proposed to ban risk insurance commissions in super but permit commissions outside super, a difference which has the potential to distort advice, he said.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">He also said the new two-year opt-in for financial planning arrangements had the potential to increase costs for consumers but said that it represented an improvement on the original one-year timeline.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Mr Gale welcomed the announcement that scaled (limited) financial advice will be extended industry-wide. "We believe the extension of scaled (limited) advice should make financial planning advice cheaper and more accessible for middle Australia, and will be an important adjunct to the new opt-in arrangements," he said.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Count will hold an analyst and media briefing next week to provide greater detail for Count shareholders.</div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>AMP Capital Investors: Weekly market &amp; economic update</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/amp-capital-investors-weekly-market-economic-update/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 29 Apr 2011 03:15:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Australian dollar]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="australian-dollar"><![CDATA[Australian dollar]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[business development]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="business-development"><![CDATA[business development]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[business growth]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="business-growth-2"><![CDATA[business growth]]></category>

		<category domain="source" nicename="dr-shane-oliver-head-of-investment-strategy-and-chief-economist-amp-capital-investors"><![CDATA[Dr Shane Oliver - Head of Investment Strategy and Chief Economist - AMP Capital Investors]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Economic Update]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="economic-update"><![CDATA[Economic Update]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[global economy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="global-economy"><![CDATA[global economy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[global financial crisis]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="global-financial-crisis"><![CDATA[global financial crisis]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[global markets]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="global-markets"><![CDATA[global markets]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[inflation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="inflation"><![CDATA[inflation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[interest rates]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="interest-rates"><![CDATA[interest rates]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="investment-strategy"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Reserve Bank]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="reserve-bank"><![CDATA[Reserve Bank]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Shane Oliver]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="shane-oliver"><![CDATA[Shane Oliver]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?p=7907</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div id="_mcePaste">
<h2>Headline developments of the past week</h2>
<div>
<ul>
	<li>There were no surprises from the US Federal Reserve’s Open Market Committee meeting and subsequent inaugural press conference by Ben Bernanke. The basic message from the Fed is that unemployment is too high and underlying inflation too low to justify monetary tightening. As a result QE2 will continue as scheduled until June and the Fed continues to see exceptionally easy monetary policy as remaining justified for an “extended period”. Ben Bernanke did provide some guidance on the path the Fed might follow when it comes time to exit from its easy monetary policy. It doesn’t regard the ending of QE2 as a monetary tightening because the Fed’s balance sheet won’t be contracting. Rather the exit path will likely first involve stopping the reinvestment of maturing assets on its balance sheet, followed by removing the commitment to keep rates low for an “extended period”, followed by a rate hike and ultimately followed by the active selling of assets on its balance sheet. This could all take a long time to unfold though and so far as already noted the Fed is not even ready to start. An outworking of the commitment to continued easy money in the US is further downwards pressure on Treasury yields, further downwards pressure on the $US, upwards pressure on precious metal prices and support for risk assets such as global shares and the $A.</li>
	<li>The Australian dollar rose above $US1.09, its highest level since January 1981. What a change a decade makes! In April 2001 the $A hit a record low of just below $US0.48. It has now more than doubled thanks to a combination of strong commodity prices and high interest rates in Australia. For some time I have expected the $A to rise to $US1.10 and we are effectively now there. So where to from here? After rising by more than 12% over six weeks the $A is due for a breather. Triggers for a correction could include RBA comments to the effect that the strong $A is reducing the pressure to raise interest rates, a likely string of earnings downgrades from Australian companies exposed to the strong $A, an intensification of concerns about a sharp downturn in China or a run of stronger US economic data. However, providing the global economic recovery continues the risk for the $A remains on the upside. Over the last decade the $A has been lagging the rise in the terms of trade but if</li>
	<li>it remains around current levels then over time its quite conceivable that the $A could rise to $US1.20 or even $US1.30 over the next few years. Just as the $A kept surprising on the downside in the 1980s and 1990s it could now just keep surprising on the upside in a three steps up one step down fashion.</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
<div style="text-align: center;"><a rel="attachment wp-att-7909" href="http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/amp-capital-investors-weekly-market-economic-update/shane-oliver-rising-dollar/"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-7909" title="Shane Oliver rising dollar" src="http://www.adviservoice.com/dev/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/Shane-Oliver-rising-dollar.png" alt="" width="334" height="194" /></a></div>
<div>
<div>
<ul>
	<li>An interesting aside – over the last decade the share of Chinese living in urban areas rose to nearly 50%, up from 36% in 2000. This means an annual increase in the urban population of 20.7 million people each year. In other words China has been needing to build the equivalent of four and half cities the size of Sydney each year just to accommodate the urban influx. Little wonder commodity demand has been so high. The Chinese urbanisation process still has a long way to go, eg in South Korea the urbanisation rate is 81.5%.</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
<h3>Major global economic releases and implications</h3>
<div>
<div>
<ul>
	<li>US GDP growth pretty much slowed as expected to an annualised pace of just 1.8% in the March quarter thanks to severe winter storms which hit consumer spending and construction activity and a detraction from trade. Other US economic data was generally better than expected with solid gains in new home and pending home sales, a modest rise in consumer confidence and a solid gain in durable goods orders. While unemployment claims rose this may reflect distortions caused by the Easter holiday. The US March quarter profit reporting season remained solid with 77% of companies coming in better than expected so far and earnings per share up 21.8% over the year to the March quarter.</li>
	<li>The March quarter earnings reporting season in Europe is also off to a solid start with 68% of results so far beating on profits and 62% beating on revenue.</li>
	<li>Japanese data for March was very weak with sharp falls in industrial production and household consumption on the back of the earthquake. Surveys suggest a partial recovery in production in subsequent months.</li>
	<li>Pressure for monetary tightening continues to build in Asia with strong economic growth in Korea in the March quarter and 5% inflation in Singapore.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h3>Australian economic releases and implications</h3>
<div>
<ul>
	<li>Australian inflation figures for the March quarter showed the fastest rise since the previous banana driven surge of June quarter 2006. However, of the 1.6% rise in headline inflation higher flood related food prices contributed 0.5 percentage points, higher petrol prices contributed 0.3 percentage points, higher utility costs contributed 0.1 percentage points, higher health costs added 0.2 percentage points, higher education contributed 0.2 percentage points. This all adds up to a 1.3 percentage point boost to inflation. By contrast the prices for market determined goods and services rose just 0.4%. So the bottom line is that underlying inflation pressures remain benign and there is not need for the RBA to rush in with a rate hike.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h3>Major market moves</h3>
<div>
<div>
<ul>
	<li>Share markets were mixed over the last week – up in Europe and the US on good earnings and economic news, up in Japan on expectations for a recovery from the impact of the earthquake but down in Asia on inflation and tightening concerns led by China. The fear of more earnings downgrades on the back of the strong Australian dollar are weighing heavily on the Australian share market though.</li>
	<li>Commodity prices were mixed with new record highs seen in gold and silver prices, a modest rise in the oil price but falls in metal prices on the back of worries about Chinese monetary tightening.</li>
	<li>Expectations for continuing easy monetary policy in the US saw the $US fall to its lowest level since 2008 and this combined with higher than expected inflation data in Australia led to a further sharp rise in the $A.</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
<h3>What to watch in the week ahead?</h3>
<div>
<div>
<ul>
	<li>In Australia, the Reserve Bank is expected to leave interest rates on hold. While inflation came in stronger than expected in the March quarter it was mainly driven by temporary factors, such as the impact of the floods on food prices, or things that the raising interest rates won’t do anything about, such as higher costs for electricity, health, education, petrol and rents. More broadly with underlying inflation remaining around the middle of the target range, the continuing surge in the value of the $A doing some of the RBA’s job for it and a run of mixed economic data over the last few weeks we expect the next rate hike won’t occur until around August. The RBA’s Statement on Monetary Policy on Friday is likely to confirm a rates on hold for now stance, but with an ongoing mild tightening bias reflecting the boost to national income from the terms of trade.</li>
	<li>On the data front in Australia, expect March quarter house price data on Monday to show a 0.5% fall in average prices for the March quarter, March building approvals data on Thursday to show a modest rise after weakness in February and March retail sales data, also due Thursday, to show modest growth.</li>
	<li>In the US, expect the ISM manufacturing conditions index due Monday to show a slight fall but remain at a high level. The ISM services conditions index due Wednesday is also expected to remain strong and payroll employment data due Friday is expected to show a 180,000 gain.</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
<h3>Outlook for markets</h3>
<div>
<div>
<ul>
	<li>While volatility will likely remain high in share markets, our broad assessment remains that shares will continue to climb the ‘wall of worry’ this year helped by still cheap valuations, the continuing global economic and profit recovery and easy global monetary conditions.</li>
	<li>The surging $A is becoming a severe dampener on Australian earnings growth and so as long as it keeps surging the Australian share market is likely to remain a laggard compared to US shares. If the $A stays around current levels it will probably knock 4 to 5 percentage points off consensus earnings growth estimates for the year ahead.</li>
	<li>Notwithstanding the likelihood of a short-term pullback, providing the global recovery continues the medium term risks are skewed to the upside for the $A, possibly to as high as $US1.20 or $US1.30.</li>
	<li>Global bonds offer poor returns given low bond yields.</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
<div>
<div class="disclaimer">Important note: While every care has been taken in the preparation of this document, AMP Capital Investors Limited (ABN 59 001 777 591) (AFSL 232497) makes no representation or warranty as to the accuracy or completeness of any statement in it including, without limitation, any forecasts. Past performance is not a reliable indicator of future performance. This document has been prepared for the purpose of providing general information, without taking account of any particular investor’s objectives, financial situation or needs. An investor should, before making any investment decisions, consider the appropriateness of the information in this document, and seek professional advice, having regard to the investor’s objectives, financial situation and needs. This document is solely for the use of the party to whom it is provided.</div>
</div>
</div>]]></content:encoded>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?p=7918</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>AustralianSuper flags a revolution in advice with adviser panel trial results</h3>
In a statement likely to have lasting implications for the financial advice and superannuation industries, AustralianSuper today declared that the FoFA reforms have created an environment in which the Fund and selected planner groups can work together in the interest of members.

The dramatic shifts in the advice and superannuation environments in the wake of the Cooper Review, the Ripoll Report and now the FoFA reforms, will lead to a shift in how Industry Super Funds and advisers work together, provided the FoFA reforms proceed in full. Although traditionally cast as enemies, according to Ian Silk, Chief Executive of AustralianSuper, the two groups should have strongly aligned interests.

Certainly the strong positive outcomes of a continuing trial involving AustralianSuper and a panel of representatives from some of Australia's leading advice firms and dealer groups provides evidence of this.

"For the past twelve months or so we have been working with advice industry leaders trialling and building a new service that will enable us to work together more effectively and in the best interest of members," said Mr Silk. "This includes addressing the vexed question of fees and other issues that have presented stumbling blocks in the past. Thus far in the trial we have worked through a number of these issues and will continue to do so as the trial continues over the next nine months or so.

"AustralianSuper has always been a major supporter of good, sound advice. What we do not support is the commission structure of so many super products that leads to conflicted advice. As we look towards new, clearer legislation relating to commissions and requiring an adviser to act in a clients best interest, we are seeing many of the more progressive advisers working to build fee-for-service and other models of advice into their practices."

Mr Silk went on to say that AustralianSuper has always focused on providing better value super through lower fees and strong long term performance and by breaking down the wall with advisers more people will now have more money in their retirement.

"Essentially we see this as part of our broader advice strategy, along with our member education programs, online and workplace seminars, our call centres and the fund's strong relationship with Industry Fund Financial Planning."

Mr Silk said that, for advisers, the trial has opened wider possibilities for advising and meeting the needs of their clients, potentially saving clients tens of thousands of dollars in fees, enabling access to a leading fund and giving advisers more control over a client's full portfolio.

"This may not have been as simple at a time where industry super funds and advisers essentially occupied separate worlds, so where a client held super outside the adviser's remit, the adviser may not have had such an opportunity."

Firms which have been participating in the trial include Godfrey Pembroke, Matrix Planning Solutions, Dixon Advisory, Woods &amp; Partners, Paul Moran, Switzer Financial Planning. They have also identified a number of advantages of the approach so far.

Tom Reddacliff, General Manager of Godfrey Pembroke said, "We are delighted to be working with AustralianSuper and believe this strategic alliance benefits our two organisations, advisers and most importantly members.

"Godfrey Pembroke was the first major licensee to introduce fee-for-advice on all new investment and superannuation clients back in 2006. Our advisers believed this was in the clients' best interests and was the right thing to do.

"This commitment to fee-for-advice closely aligns our organisations and makes Godfrey Pembroke a natural provider of trusted financial advice to AustralianSuper members. Furthermore, Godfrey Pembroke guarantees it will not receive a single cent of commission from any AustralianSuper member."

Another participant in the trial, Rick Di Cristoforo, Managing Director of independently owned advice firm Matrix Planning Solutions, said "Matrix has always been committed to providing quality advice, including administration and product solutions that are best suited to our clients' needs.

"Our research confirms our belief that industry funds can play an important role as an efficient and competitive superannuation solution for a wide cross section of working Australians, and in our view, AustralianSuper is a clear market leader.

"We are delighted to be working with AustralianSuper as part of this advice partnership."

As the trial continues, the focus is on continuing to resolve various logistical issues associated with ensuring a smooth and workable proposition for all concerned.

Ian Silk further states, "What we are most pleased about is that the fundamentals are sound. We have the ingredients and commitment we need to meet our mutual aims and that can only be the start of a very good thing for members."

<div class="disclaimer">This information is of a general nature and does not take into account your personal objectives, situations or needs. Before making a decision about AustralianSuper, consider your financial requirements and read our Product Disclosure Statement, available at <a href="https://mail.inqbase.com/exchweb/bin/redir.asp?URL=http://www.australiansuper.com/FormsPublications" target="_blank">www.australiansuper.com/FormsPublications</a> or by calling 1300 300 273. AustralianSuper Pty Ltd ABN 94 006 457 987 AFSL 233788, Trustee of AustralianSuper ABN 65 714 394 898. 'Industry SuperFund logo used with permission of Industry Fund Services (IFS). This consent had not been withdrawn as at the date of this publication.</div>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>CommSec: Record quarterly fall in home prices</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/commsec-record-quarterly-fall-in-home-prices/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 29 Apr 2011 04:13:54 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Commsec]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="commsec"><![CDATA[Commsec]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[consumers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="consumers"><![CDATA[consumers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[economic data]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="economic-data"><![CDATA[economic data]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Economic Update]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="economic-update"><![CDATA[Economic Update]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Financial planners]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-planners"><![CDATA[Financial planners]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[house prices]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="house-prices"><![CDATA[house prices]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[housing sector]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="housing-sector"><![CDATA[housing sector]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[interest rates]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="interest-rates"><![CDATA[interest rates]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="investment-strategy"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[private sector credit]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="private-sector-credit"><![CDATA[private sector credit]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Reserve Bank]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="reserve-bank"><![CDATA[Reserve Bank]]></category>

		<category domain="source" nicename="savanth-sebastian-economist-commsec"><![CDATA[Savanth Sebastian - Economist - CommSec]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?p=7922</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>House Prices; Private Sector Credit</h2>
<ul>
<blockquote>
	<li>Capital city home prices fell by 0.2 per cent in seasonally adjusted terms in March after a downwardly revised 0.5 per cent slide in February, according to the RP Data-Rismark Hedonic Australian Home Value Index – the largest property database in Australia. Outside capital cities, prices rose by 0.2 per cent in March.</li>
	<li>Capital city home prices fell by 2.1 per cent over the first three months of the year – marking the largest quarterly slide in property prices on record. Prices in the ‘Rest of State’ markets were down 0.5 per cent in annualised terms.</li>
	<li>Prices rose in just two of the seven capital cities in March with Darwin prices up 1.1 per cent, followed by Melbourne up 0.6 per cent. Prices fell most in Perth (down 1.9 per cent), Brisbane (down 1.4 per cent), followed by Adelaide (down 0.7 per cent). Sydney prices were unchanged in March.</li>
	<li>Private sector credit rose by 0.6 per cent in March to stand 3.6 per cent higher than a year ago. Housing credit grew by 6.6 per cent in annual terms marking the weakest annual growth rate in records going back 34 years.</li>
</blockquote>
</ul>
<h3>What does it all mean?</h3>
<div>
<ul>
	<li>Over the past six months we have made mention of the inevitable consolidation in the housing sector and it certainly seems to be in full swing. In fact over the first three months of 2011 property prices have fallen by 2.1 per cent marking the biggest quarterly slide in records going back seven years. And even in annual terms prices have recorded the first fall in two years. Whichever way you look at it the housing sector is decidedly weak, and more importantly there is no silver lining on the horizon to suggest a turnaround in fortunes is likely anytime soon.</li>
	<li>The sizeable 19 per cent slide in housing finance commitments over the first two months of 2001 clearly highlights the lack of home buyer interest. Added to which the latest private sector credit figures have revealed that housing credit has posted the weakest annual growth in records going back 33 years. The recent slide in property prices and more circumspect home buyers will result in sellers being more realistic about achievable prices in coming months.</li>
	<li>Effectively you can strike another item off the Reserve Bank’s worry list. The rate hikes delivered over 2010 have taken the heat out of the housing market ensuring that the normal supply-demand fundamentals are ruling the roost across capital city housing markets.</li>
	<li>Interestingly there are marked differences in home prices across the nation and it is a similar story when you look at rental yields. States like NSW has seen a significant amount of under building compared to the likes Victoria however the lack of supply – lower vacancy rates – in NSW has resulted in higher rental yields on offer.</li>
	<li>It is important to highlight that while the housing sector is cooling it is not about to collapse in a heap. Overall CommSec expects house prices to consolidate over the next few months, but for the year as a whole we would expect prices to lift by 5 per cent. The Reserve Bank is likely to remain on the interest rate sidelines in the near term, while healthy jobs growth, rising population and sliding rental vacancy rates will support housing activity in the medium term.</li>
	<li>The Australian economy has certainly lost momentum over the last couple of months. However the latest improvement in private sector credit is certainly encouraging especially given that modest increases have taken place over the last few months.</li>
	<li>Admittedly it is too early to claim a full blown turnaround borrowing activity, but it does seem like the lack of rate hikes over the past few months is allowing businesses and consumers to get back to basics. Personal credit recorded its best monthly increase since late 2009, added to which businesses borrowing also recorded its best monthly gain in 2½ years. The pickup in borrowings does have the potential to boost spending levels in coming months. It should be noted that the impact of the natural disasters may have artificially inflated the pickup in borrowings, but there has been signs of a modest improvement nonetheless.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h3><a rel="attachment wp-att-7923" href="http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/commsec-record-quarterly-fall-in-home-prices/savanth-commsec-buying-interest-and-on-the-slide/"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-7923" title="Savanth Commsec Buying Interest and On the Slide" src="http://www.adviservoice.com/dev/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/Savanth-Commsec-Buying-Interest-and-On-the-Slide.png" alt="" width="642" height="244" /></a></h3>
<h3>What do the figures show?</h3>
<div>

<span style="text-decoration: underline;">House price prices</span>
<ul>
	<li><strong><span style="font-weight: normal;">The RP Data-Rismark Hedonic Australian Home Value Index fell by 0.2 per cent in March after a downwardly revised 0.5 per cent fall in the previous month.</span></strong></li>
	<li>House prices fell by 0.2 per cent in the month while apartments fell by 0.3 per cent.</li>
	<li>Capital city home (dwelling) prices are down 0.6 per cent on a year ago – marking the first annual slide in property prices in two years. House prices are down 1.2 per cent and apartment prices are up by 1.4 per cent.</li>
	<li>Prices rose in just two of the seven capital cities in March with Darwin prices up 1.1 per cent, followed by Melbourne (up 0.6 per cent). Across the other cities prices fell most in Perth (down 1.9 per cent), Brisbane (down 1.4 per cent), Adelaide (down 0.7 per cent) and Canberra (down 0.4 per cent). Sydney prices were unchanged in March, while Hobart prices rose by 2.3 per cent in February (March data not yet available).</li>
	<li>Home prices are higher than a year ago in just Sydney (up 2.1 per cent) and Melbourne (up 1.0 per cent). Prices fell the most in Brisbane (down 6.8 per cent), Perth (down 6.4per cent), Darwin (down 1.3 per cent) and Canberra (down 0.5 per cent). Adelaide prices were unchanged on a year ago.</li>
	<li>March home prices aren’t available yet for Hobart. In the year to February, home prices in Hobart were down by 1.3 per cent.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Private sector credit</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">
<ul>
	<li>Private sector credit (lending) rose by 0.6 per cent in March after rising by 0.5 per cent in February. Credit growth is up 3.6 per cent on a year ago.</li>
	<li>Housing credit grew by 0.4 per cent with lending to owner-occupiers rising by 0.4 per cent and investor housing up 0.2 per cent. Housing credit is up 6.6 per cent on a year ago – the weakest annual growth in records going back 34 years. Owner occupier housing credit is up 6.5 per cent on a year ago - slowest pace in records going back 20 years. Investor housing lending was up 6.7 per cent on a year ago.</li>
	<li>Personal credit remained rose by 0.6 per cent in March after rising by 0.2 per cent in February. Personal credit was up 1.0 per cent over the year – still well below the rate of inflation. Business credit rose by 1.0 per cent in March, however was down 0.6 per cent on a year ago.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h3><a rel="attachment wp-att-7925" href="http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/commsec-record-quarterly-fall-in-home-prices/savanth-flattening-prices-and-consumers-confident/"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-7925" title="Savanth Flattening Prices and Consumers confident" src="http://www.adviservoice.com/dev/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/Savanth-Flattening-Prices-and-Consumers-confident.png" alt="" width="654" height="239" /></a></h3>
<h3>What is the importance of the economic data?</h3>
<div id="_mcePaste">
<ul>
	<li>The RP Data-Rismark Hedonic Australian Home Value Index is based on Australia’s biggest property database covering more than 340,000 sales during 2010. Unlike the ABS Index, which excludes terraces, semidetached homes and apartments, the RP Data-Rismark Hedonic Index includes all properties.</li>
	<li>The monthly RP Data-Rismark Hedonic Index compares month-to-month index results. Quarterly results are measured comparing end months rather than averaging each month in the quarter. For example, the first quarter of 2009 index results would compare the end of March index with the end of December index.</li>
	<li>Private sector credit figures are released by the Reserve Bank on the last working day of the month. Credit is separated into three categories – housing, other personal and business. Private sector credit is effectively the amount of loans outstanding in the economy. If growth in lending is strong then it suggests that credit from financial institutions is freely available, underlying demand for assets such as cars and houses is firm and that the price of credit (interest rates) is attractive.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h3>What are the implications for interest rates and investors?</h3>
<div id="_mcePaste">
<ul>
	<li>The rate hikes have certainly taken their toll on the housing sector over the past year and unfortunately for the sector it is unlikely that a turnaround is going to take place anytime soon. Overall CommSec expects house prices to consolidate over the next few months, but for the year as a whole we would expect prices to lift by 5 per cent.</li>
	<li>A softening in home prices combined with the prospect of interest rates remaining unchanged for the next few months is clearly positive for budding home buyers. Less doom and gloom stories about interest rates and unsustainable home prices will be beneficial for consumer sentiment more generally.</li>
	<li>The improvement in consumer and business credit is certainly encouraging, but to claim a sustained improvement the Reserve Bank will need to stay on the interest rate sidelines for another couple of months. More importantly there is nothing in the data to date to force the Reserve Bank to raise interest rate in the near term.</li>
</ul>
<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-7927" title="Savanth encouraging turnaround and home buyers" src="http://www.adviservoice.com/dev/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/Savanth-encouraging-turnaround-and-home-buyers.png" alt="" width="659" height="281" />

</div>
<div class="disclaimer">Produced by Commonwealth Research based on information available at the time of publishing. We believe that the information in this report is correct and any opinions, conclusions or recommendations are reasonably held or made as at the time of its compilation, but no warranty is made as to accuracy, reliability or completeness. To the extent permitted by law, neither Commonwealth Bank of Australia ABN 48 123 123 124 nor any of its subsidiaries accept liability to any person for loss or damage arising from the use of this report. The report has been prepared without taking account of the objectives, financial situation or needs of any particular individual. For this reason, any individual should, before acting on the information in this report, consider the appropriateness of the information, having regard to the individual’s objectives, financial situation and needs and, if necessary, seek appropriate professional advice. This report is approved and distributed in the UK by Commonwealth Bank of Australia incorporated in Australia with limited liability. Registered in England No. BR250 and regulated in the UK by the Financial Services Authority (FSA). For the purpose of the FSA rules, this report and related services are not intended for private customers and are not available to them. Commonwealth Bank of Australia and its subsidiaries have effected or may effect transactions for their own account in any investments or related investments referred to in this report.</div>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Lonsec releases its Global Equity Fund Sector Review</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/04/lonsec-releases-its-global-equity-fund-sector-review/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 29 Apr 2011 06:37:13 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[consumers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="consumers"><![CDATA[consumers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[consumption]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="consumption"><![CDATA[consumption]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Emerging Markets]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="emerging-markets"><![CDATA[Emerging Markets]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[global growth]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="global-growth"><![CDATA[global growth]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[global markets]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="global-markets"><![CDATA[global markets]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[investment]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="investment"><![CDATA[investment]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="investment-strategy"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[large cap]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="large-cap"><![CDATA[large cap]]></category>

		<category domain="source" nicename="lonsec-limited"><![CDATA[Lonsec Limited]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[shares]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="shares"><![CDATA[shares]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Small Cap]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="small-cap"><![CDATA[Small Cap]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[stock market]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="stock-market"><![CDATA[stock market]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Trends]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="trends"><![CDATA[Trends]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?p=7942</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<blockquote>Lonsec's latest Global Equity Fund Sector Review included 36 large cap and three small cap funds.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>Of these, nine large cap funds attained Lonsec's top rating, Highly Recommended, including T. Rowe Price Global Equity Fund, Arrowstreet Global Equity Fund, Templeton Global Equities Fund, Aberdeen International Equity Fund (upgraded) and new entrant to Lonsec‟s universe, IFP Global Franchise Fund.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>Rui Fernandes, Senior Investment Analyst responsible for reviewing the sector, commented, "The distribution of product ratings were broadly stable across both the most recent and the previous sector review seasons."</blockquote>
<h2><span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span><strong>Sector themes and observations</strong></h2>
<h3><strong><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
<span style="color: #000000;">Great minds think alike</span></strong><strong>
</strong></h3>
<span style="font-weight: normal;">“The degree of 'commonality' across Top 10 holdings is a curious and surprising outcome,” said Fernandes.
</span><span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>“Only 172 different stocks held these highest conviction positions across the 26 portfolios – a remarkable observation considering that notionally, there is the potential for 260 different stocks (26x10) to occupy these positions out of some 1,500 in the MSCI World Index.”
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>Companies that featured in several portfolios included Roche (which featured most prominently across the "Top 10‟ holdings, notably across seven of 26), Phillip Morris International, Nestle, Pfizer, Vodafone, Apple, Google, Hewlett Packard, Johnson &amp; Johnson, and Wells Fargo.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>Fernandes commented, “The funds management industry's process-driven stock assessments, with similar modelling and assumption methodologies, may be a significant driver of this outcome.”
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>“However, there is also the possibility that an undeterminable degree of  'herding' (e.g. safety in numbers) may also be the cause, which may or may not be a conscious decision by investment managers.”
<strong><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></strong>
<h3><strong>Investment teams and portfolios stabilise</strong></h3>
In last year's report Lonsec noted that investment managers had mirrored the companies they invested in by seeking to control costs, with consequences for their investment teams. By contrast, this year's review observed that investment teams were, on the whole, relatively stable.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
“Voluntary turnover has been witnessed across some managers but overall the trend has been muted,” said Fernandes.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
In last year's report Lonsec noted that investment managers had mirrored the companies they invested in by seeking to control costs, with consequences for their investment teams. By contrast, this year's review observed that investment teams were, on the whole, relatively stable.
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
“Voluntary turnover has been witnessed across some managers but overall the trend has been muted,” said Fernandes.

“In response to the changing global growth dynamics, managers have been flagging their intention to 'beef up' their Asian coverage, either with transfers from their European or US offices or new regional appointments.”

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
<h3><strong>Asia still sparkling</strong></h3>
<span style="font-weight: normal;">Most investment managers tended to be mildly positive on the overall outlook for global markets, a noticeable change from the cautionary tone observed in last year's review. However, the outlook for Asia, particularly for the Emerging Asian Region, was positive and continued to be the brightest star in the investment landscape.
</span><span style="color: #ffffff; font-weight: normal;">x</span>

<span style="font-weight: normal;">Fernandes observed, “Many see the main opportunity to be the rise of the middle class and increased consumption through the step-up in per capita income. This is believed to touch many sectors ranging from Financials and Consumer Discretionary.”</span>

<span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span>
<h3><span style="font-weight: normal;"><strong>Emerging markets – more than one way to ‘play’ the story</strong></span></h3>
<span style="font-weight: normal;">“While managers may disagree on the 'cheapness' or 'richness' (in terms of price) of emerging markets stocks in general, most did not dispute the long-term trends that are favourable for these investments,” commented Fernandes.</span>
<span style="color: #ffffff; font-weight: normal;">x</span>
<span style="font-weight: normal;">“Managers generally fell into two camps – those that 'played' emerging market stocks directly and those 'played' them indirectly. For example, Nestle is a developed-market consumer staple stock whose incremental growth has been sourced from emerging markets. The incremental growth from emerging economies was a key attraction of the stock.”</span><span style="font-weight: normal;">
</span><span style="font-weight: normal;">The Lonsec report highlights that most managers had a degree of direct emerging market exposure at the time of review</span>

<span style="font-weight: normal;">Of the 26 qualitative products reviewed in this sector, Lonsec observed that there was a notable degree of "commonality" in the "Top 10" holdings as at June 2010 – the stocks considered to be a fundamental manager's highest conviction positions, being the largest absolute/active weights.</span>
<div class="disclaimer">IMPORTANT NOTICE: The following relate to this document published by Lonsec Limited ABN 56 061 751 102 ("Lonsec") and should be read before making any investment decision about the product(s). Disclosure at the date of publication: Lonsec receive a fee from the fund manager for rating the product(s) using comprehensive and objective criteria. Lonsec‟s fee is not linked to the rating outcome. Lonsec does not hold the product(s) referred to in this document. Lonsec‟s representatives and/or their associates may hold the product(s) referred to in this document, but detail of these holdings are not known to the Analyst(s). Warnings: Past performance is not a reliable indicator of future performance. Any express or implied rating or advice presented in this document is limited to “General Advice” and based solely on consideration of the investment merits of the financial product(s) alone, without taking into account the investment objectives, financial situation and particular needs („financial circumstances‟) of any particular person. Before making an investment decision based on the rating or advice, the reader must consider whether it is personally appropriate in light of his or her financial circumstances or should seek further advice on its appropriateness. If our General Advice relates to the acquisition or possible acquisition of particular financial product(s), the reader should obtain and consider the Product Disclosure Statement for each financial product before making any decision about whether to acquire a product. Disclaimer: This document is for the exclusive use of the person to whom it is provided by Lonsec and must not be used or relied upon by any other person. No representation, warranty or undertaking is given or made in relation to the accuracy or completeness of the information presented in this document, which is drawn from public information not verified by Lonsec. Conclusions, ratings and advice are reasonably held at the time of completion but subject to change without notice. Lonsec assumes no obligation to update this document following publication. Except for any liability which cannot be excluded, Lonsec, its directors, employees and agents disclaim all liability for any error or inaccuracy in, or omission from, this document or any loss or damage suffered by the reader or any other person as a consequence of relying upon it.</div>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>Are your investments too home biased?</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/2011/05/are-your-investments-too-home-biased/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 02 May 2011 00:26:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[asset allocation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="asset-allocation"><![CDATA[asset allocation]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Australian dollar]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="australian-dollar"><![CDATA[Australian dollar]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[consumers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="consumers"><![CDATA[consumers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[economic conditions]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="economic-conditions"><![CDATA[economic conditions]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Emerging Markets]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="emerging-markets"><![CDATA[Emerging Markets]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[equity assets]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="equity-assets"><![CDATA[equity assets]]></category>

		<category domain="source" nicename="fil-investment-management-australia-limited"><![CDATA[FIL Investment Management (Australia) Limited]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[financial advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-advisers"><![CDATA[financial advisers]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Financial planning]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="financial-planning-2"><![CDATA[Financial planning]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[global markets]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="global-markets"><![CDATA[global markets]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="investment-strategy"><![CDATA[Investment strategy]]></category>

		<category domain="tag"><![CDATA[investors]]></category>

		<category domain="tag" nicename="investors"><![CDATA[investors]]></category>

		<category><![CDATA[Managers Corner]]></category>

		<category domain="category" nicename="managers-corner"><![CDATA[Managers Corner]]></category>

		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?p=7963</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div id="_mcePaste">While globalisation has been a significant trend in business over the past few decades, it still has yet to gain acceptance among individual investors according to Tom Stevenson, Investment Director at Fidelity.</div>
<div></div>
<div></div>
<div>While the investment industry has become global, many investors still have significant bias towards their home markets, overlooking other faster-growing markets.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff; -webkit-border-horizontal-spacing: 2px; -webkit-border-vertical-spacing: 2px; line-height: normal; font-size: x-small;">x</span></div>
<h3>Shifting global economic power</h3>
<div>Undoubtedly one of the most important secular themes of our age is the ongoing shift in economic power away from developed countries to leading emerging markets such as China and India. This ongoing power shift is underpinned by a host of supportive factors in emerging markets, including strong growth, rising incomes, favourable demographics and enhanced macro-stability.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff; -webkit-border-horizontal-spacing: 2px; -webkit-border-vertical-spacing: 2px; line-height: normal; font-size: x-small;">x</span></div>
<div>It is notable that many of the most successful and savviest of western businesses have been actively seeking to expand their operations beyond their traditional home markets to less developed but higher growth markets. For example, drinks giant Coca-Cola now derives around three quarters of its revenues from outside of its traditional North American home market and the company’s relatively early entry into emerging markets is now being credited for the company’s strong sales and profit performance of recent years.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff; -webkit-border-horizontal-spacing: 2px; -webkit-border-vertical-spacing: 2px; line-height: normal; font-size: x-small;">x</span></div>
<h3>But significant home bias remains in investor portfolios</h3>
<div>Have investors exhibited the same level of far-sightedness as the likes of Coca-Cola when it comes to their investment portfolios? The evidence suggests not.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff; -webkit-border-horizontal-spacing: 2px; -webkit-border-vertical-spacing: 2px; line-height: normal; font-size: x-small;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Reflective of their strong growth, the share of emerging markets in the market cap-weighted MSCI AC World Index has risen from around 4.5% at the end of 2003 to 13.6% at present. Goldman Sachs forecasts that this share will rise further to 19% and 31% respectively in 2020 and 2030, with China alone projected to account for 13% of the index in 2030.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff; -webkit-border-horizontal-spacing: 2px; -webkit-border-vertical-spacing: 2px; line-height: normal; font-size: x-small;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">However, research conducted by Fidelity shows that investor allocations have not kept any semblance of pace with the growth of investable assets in emerging markets and global markets. Other studies have revealed similar home biases. For example, towards the end of 2010, data from the IMA showed that UK investors had just 3.5% of their assets in emerging markets, which was more than 10 percentage points lower than the share of emerging market equities in the MSCI AC World Index.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff; -webkit-border-horizontal-spacing: 2px; -webkit-border-vertical-spacing: 2px; line-height: normal; font-size: x-small;">x</span></div>
<h3>Explaining the sources of bias</h3>
<div>A wide range of reasons have been suggested for investors’ persistent inclination towards their home markets at the expense of global markets. Some of these reasons have quite rational underpinnings, such as informational disadvantages and regulatory limits that militate against foreign investment. However, the overall global trend in the past few decades has been towards a lessening of these kinds of factors.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff; -webkit-border-horizontal-spacing: 2px; -webkit-border-vertical-spacing: 2px; line-height: normal; font-size: x-small;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Although some meaningful limitations for outward foreign investment remain, notably currency risk (which can be hedged), this is not sufficient to explain the full extent of investor home bias that is still in evidence today in many countries.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff; -webkit-border-horizontal-spacing: 2px; -webkit-border-vertical-spacing: 2px; line-height: normal; font-size: x-small;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Instead, it is very likely that home bias is due in large part to behavioural factors. For example, this may include familiarity biases – a preference for assets or ‘names’ that are simply more familiar-sounding to investors, which in turn may be based on assumptions about having an information advantage over things that are in closer proximity to them.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff; -webkit-border-horizontal-spacing: 2px; -webkit-border-vertical-spacing: 2px; line-height: normal; font-size: x-small;">x</span></div>
<h3>The costs of home bias</h3>
<div>If investors are biased towards their home investment markets this may mean that they are not taking advantage of the diversification opportunities that are available to them from global investing. In more technical terms, investors that exhibit home bias may receive inferior risk-adjusted returns from their portfolios as a result.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff; -webkit-border-horizontal-spacing: 2px; -webkit-border-vertical-spacing: 2px; line-height: normal; font-size: x-small;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">If global emerging markets’ share of GDP and global equity market capitalisation continues to rise as expected, then this is likely to require more representative allocations from investors in developed markets. For example, Goldman Sachs recently forecast that the weighting of developed market institutional asset managers to emerging market equities would rise from the current 6% to 18% by 2030. If overall flows towards emerging market equities rise in this way, then this in itself may be a highly supportive factor for emerging market equity performance.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff; -webkit-border-horizontal-spacing: 2px; -webkit-border-vertical-spacing: 2px; line-height: normal; font-size: x-small;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">While globalisation seems to be among the most influential themes of our time, the evidence suggests that it is not happening among local investors. Many local investors are under-exposed to global assets, including global equities and emerging market equities. Investors should consider evaluating their portfolios and the existence of any unwarranted home biases and whether a higher allocation to faster-growing global and emerging market assets might be necessary.</div>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>FPA: SQM Research - The Housing Market and the Wealth Effect </title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/event/fpa-sqm-research-the-housing-market-and-the-wealth-effect/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 02 May 2011 00:51:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=7969</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Guest speaker, Louis Christopher, Managing Director SQM Research

Whether we love it or hate it, the housing market is a considerable driver behind the greater economy. With an estimated value of some 5.1 trillion dollars, housing dwarfs the share market in terms of its size. Yet, in terms of access to information, housing data lacks the transparency that the share market takes for granted, and property investors struggle to find truly independent experts in the market place. Here lies an opportunity for the financial planning community in that, they can access reliable information on behalf of their clients. Financial planners could be the perfect independent experts in the market place, or at least be a superior provider of information compared to traditional real estate agents. In any case, the market is now facing a major downturn, which potentially could be larger than the brief correction recorded in 2008. Louis Christopher, one of the country's leading and independent property analysts will give you a detailed and insight snapshot of the current state of the market.
<div id="_mcePaste">Cost: Free to members and their guests</div>
<div id="_mcePaste">RSVP:	Thursday 12 May 2011</div>
<div id="_mcePaste">CPD:	To be advised</div>
Cost: Free to members and their guests

RSVP:	Thursday 12 May 2011

CPD:	To be advised

<a href="http://www.fpa.asn.au/media/FPA/Website%20files/Events_/Events%20WA_ACT/EventsACT_TechnicalWorkshopInvitationMay11.pdf">Click to download the registration form for this event</a>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>FPA: CPD Live Webinar “2011 Federal Budget – what it means to you”</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/event/fpa-cpd-live-webinar-2011-federal-budget-what-it-really-means-to-you/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 02 May 2011 01:04:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=7971</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<table border="0" cellspacing="2" cellpadding="2">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td>Presenters, Tim Wedd and Sue Merriman  from Financial Review Professional Education

This year's Federal Budget is expected to kickstart the legislative process, spelling out the detail of broad policies previously announced, as well as lay the groundwork for further potential government reforms.

In this CPD Live &amp; Online session, Sue Merriman and Tim Wedd, renowned industry technical experts, will share their insights on what the Budget may mean for you and your clients in this interactive online Q&amp;A environment.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td align="undefined" valign="undefined">
<div id="_mcePaste"></div>
<div>Cost: $77.00 Members, $110.00 Non-Members</div>
<div></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">RSVP:	Monday 16 May 2011</div>
<div></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">CPD:	1.5 points</div>
<div></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Registration:	<a href="http://www.cpdlive.com/fpa/seminars/displaySeminar.html?Seminar__seminar_id=1060&amp;Series__series_id=1615">Click here to download the registration form</a></div></td>

		<item>
		<title>FPA: Estate Planning - enhancing your business, your client&#039;s trust and you! </title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/event/fpa-estate-planning-enhancing-your-business-your-clients-trust-and-you/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 02 May 2011 01:15:40 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=7972</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Guest speakers, Scott Hay-Bartlem &amp; Neil Kendall, CFP

Find out how to make sure clients follow through with your estate planning recommendations and how you can proactively engage their interaction. You will hear and see some successful strategies for "encouraging" clients in the process.
<div>Scott Hay-Bartlem will discuss how his firm works with planners to obtain great estate planning results for clients and Neil Kendall will provide tips from his experience on practical steps to turn estate planning into a valuable client service.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div>Cost: $44.00 Members, $66.00 Non-Members; $319.00 Table of 8</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">RSVP:	Tuesday 10 May 2011</div>

		<title>FPA:Advanced Aged Care &amp; A-Z of Retirement Homes Combined Workshop</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/event/fpaadvanced-aged-care-a-z-of-retirement-homes-combined-workshop/</link>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div id="_mcePaste">Overview: Louise Biti and Richard Andrews</div>
<div id="_mcePaste"><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">This comprehensive full day program brings together two of our most popular sessions to help you expand your advice proposition into the increasing domain of Aged Care advice</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">In the morning, leading industry expert Louise Biti will provide you with the technical strategies and practical steps on how to advise your aging clients. The second session, with presenter Richard Andrews will focus in on Retirement Homes and how to guide your clients and their families through the pitfalls of the villages and purchase negotiations.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Cost: $595.00 Members , $795.00 Non Members</div>

<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>

		<title>FPA: Federal Budget Luncheon, guest speaker The Hon Mal Brough</title>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Overview</h3>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Guest speaker, The Hon Mal Brough</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Former Australian Politician, Liberal Party</div>
<div id="_mcePaste"><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">In conjunction with Financial Planning Week, the FPA Sunshine Coast Chapter is pleased to invite you to the 2011 Federal Budget Luncheon.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">We welcome The Hon Mal Brough who will discuss the Federal Budget Update detailing the Coast Economy and recent government policy changes relating to the Financial Planning Profession.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Cost: $15.00 Members, $20.00 Non-Members</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">RSVP:	 Tuesday 17 May 2011</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">CPD:	 1.5 points</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Registration:	 <a href="http://www.fpa.asn.au/media/FPA/Website%20files/Events_/Events%20QLD_NT/EventsQLD_SunshineCoastFederalBudgetUpdate.pdf">Click here to download the registration form</a></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>FPA: Advanced Aged Care &amp; A-Z of Retirement Homes Combined Workshop</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/event/fpa-advanced-aged-care-a-z-of-retirement-homes-combined-workshop/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 02 May 2011 02:54:13 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=7978</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Overview</h3>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div><span style="color: #000000;">Advanced Aged Care &amp; A-Z of Retirement Homes Combined Workshop</span></div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Presenters: Louise Biti and Richard Andrews</div>
<div id="_mcePaste"><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">This comprehensive full day program brings together two of our most popular sessions to help you expand your advice proposition into the increasing domain of Aged Care advice</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">In the morning, leading industry expert Louise Biti will provide you with the technical strategies and practical steps on how to advise your aging clients. The second session, with presenter Richard Andrews will focus in on Retirement Homes and how to guide your clients and their families through the pitfalls of the villages and purchase negotiations.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Cost: $595.00 Members , $795.00 Non Members</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">RSVP:	 Friday 20 May, 2011</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">CPD:	 To be advised</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Registration: <a href="http://www.fpa.asn.au/default.asp?action=article&amp;ID=21786">Click to download registration form</a></div>]]></content:encoded>

							</item>
		<item>
		<title>FPA: Building and Sustaining a Profitable Financial Planning Business </title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/event/fpa-building-and-sustaining-a-profitable-financial-planning-business/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 02 May 2011 03:02:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=7979</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Overview</h3>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Guest speakers: Alisdair Barr, Head of Financial Planning, and Vicky Ampoulos, National Business Development Manager</div>
<div>Commonwealth Financial Planning, Pathways</div>
<div id="_mcePaste"><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">The financial planning landscape is rapidly changing. How your business is positioned in the wake of these reforms will determine how well you can continue to deliver quality advice to your clients. This highly interactive workshop will focus on the following outcomes and will help you: " Understand the changing financial planning landscape and what this means for your business "	Learn about the key ingredients of successful financial panning businesses "	Gain insights in how you can grow your business "	Understand the support you need to keep growing a successful business "	Learn how to get new clients without it costing you a cent A workbook will be provided for each participant to ensure that you have something practical to take away and implement in your business straight away.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Cost: $35.00 Members; $55.00 Non members</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">RSVP:	 Thursday 19 May 2011</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">CPD:	 To be advised</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Registration:	 <a href="http://www.fpa.asn.au/media/FPA/Website%20files/Events_/Events%20WA_ACT/EventsACT_CPDSeminarMay11.pdf">Click here to download the registration form</a></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>FPA: Budget Breakfast</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/event/fpa-budget-breakfast/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 02 May 2011 03:36:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=7981</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Overview</h3>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Guest speaker: Emmanuel Calligeris, Chief Investment Officer, ING Investment Management</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">We welcome Emmanuel Calligeris who will provide an Economic Outlook for the Australian economy, with an emphasis on the role the budget will play in the economic performance of Australia over the next year. What is the likely growth path, given the debate over carbon tax changes and what are the risks to the Australian economy?</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">This is a valuable opportunity for you to host a table and entertain your clients with a quality guest speaker in attendance.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Cost: $44.00 Per person, $320.00 Table of 8</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">RSVP:	 Monday 17 2011</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">CPD:	 To be advised</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Registration:	 <a href="http://www.fpa.asn.au/media/FPA/Website%20files/Events_/Events%20QLD_NT/EventsNT_FPWeek_BudgetBreakfast.pdf">Click here to download the registration form</a></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Overview</h3>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Louise Biti and Richard Andrews</div>
<div id="_mcePaste"><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">This comprehensive full day program brings together two of our most popular sessions to help you expand your advice proposition into the increasing domain of Aged Care advice.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">In the morning, leading industry expert Louise Biti will provide you with the technical strategies and practical steps on how to advise your aging clients. The second session, with presenter Richard Andrews will focus in on Retirement Homes and how to guide your clients and their families through the pitfalls of the villages and purchase negotiations.</div>

		<title>FPA:Life Risk Advice - positioning and optimising cover for your clients</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/event/fpalife-risk-advice-positioning-and-optimising-cover-for-your-clients/</link>

		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Overview</h3>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">
</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Presenter: Sue Laing, The Risk Store</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Just like investment advising, professional life risk advising requires the right knowledge and capacity to follow a process that results in good advice that your clients understand, value and follow. In this workshop, Risk Guru Sue Laing shares with you her proven methodology and technical know-how to construct contemporary risk advice and communicate your Life Risk value proposition successfully with your clients.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Cost: $355.00 Members , $455.00 Non-Members</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>

		<item>
		<title>AFA Female Excellence in Advice Award Launch Event</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/event/afa-female-excellence-in-advice-award-launch-event/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 02 May 2011 04:03:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=7985</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div id="_mcePaste">Launch of the Association of Financial Advisers (AFA) Female Excellence in Advice Award.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">X</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">Be a part of an industry-wide program designed to:</div>
<div id="_mcePaste">
<ul>
	<li>encourage more females to join the financial advisory profession;</li>
	<li>support greater participation by females in leadership roles within the profession;</li>
	<li>provide clients with more choice when obtaining advice;</li>
	<li>address the gender imbalance in Australia’s underinsurance and retirement savings.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div id="_mcePaste"><span style="color: #ffffff;">
</span></div>
<div>Hear from two inspirational speakers: Professor The Honourable Jennifer Boland and AFA Political Strategist Kerry Chikarovski, both recognised for excellence in their fields.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<div id="_mcePaste">They offer a uniquely female perspective on achieving success and the challenges that are encountered along the way.</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<a href="http://www.afa.asn.au/documents/mediacentre/events/2011/AFA%20-%20Female%20Excellence%20in%20Advice%20Award%20invite%20(A4)%20final.pdf">click to view details</a>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
		<title>AFA: The Future of Financial Advice in Australia post FOFA &amp; Budget</title>
		<link>http://www.adviservoice.com/event/7986/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 02 May 2011 04:11:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[HelenS]]></dc:creator>
		
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.adviservoice.com/?post_type=sp_events&#038;p=7986</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The AFA is delighted to have Senator Mathias Cormann join us to address the following key topic: The Future of Financial Advice in Australia
<ul>
	<li>Post FOFA &amp; Post Budget</li>
	<li>The Oppositions Perspective</li>
</ul>
<span style="color: #ffffff;">x
</span>In addition the Senator will address his insights into the FoFA reforms.

Following his presentation Senator Cormann will be happy to answer questions on a range  of topics relevant to Financial Advisers.

Closing Date: Friday 13 May 2011
<div>Cost: $75 AFA members  - $90 Non members, Tables of 10 @ $900</div>
<div><span style="color: #ffffff;">x</span></div>
<a href="http://www.afa.asn.au/documents/mediacentre/events/2011/AFA%20-%20Breakfast%20with%20Mathias%20Cormann%20invite%20v4.pdf">Click here to view registration details</a>]]></content:encoded>
